Much like hepatitis A, the fatality rate is low, with the exception\nof pregnant women, where it can reach 20 percent among those infected\nin the 3rd trimester.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis a", "hepatitis e", "yellow fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Karamoja", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kaabong", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "697667", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hepatitis E - France: (SE), autochthonous & food-borne", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=697667", "date": "2011-04-12 21:42:06", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E - FRANCE: (SOUTHEAST), AUTOCHTHONOUS AND FOOD-BORNE\n***************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 Apr 2011\nFrom: Philippe Colson [edited]\n<philippe.colson@univmed.fr>\n\n\nAutochthonous hepatitis E -- Marseille, southeastern France\n------------------------------------------------------------\nWe report on 11 hepatitis E virus (HEV) infections diagnosed from\nJanuary through March 2011 by PCR and serology in our microbiology lab\nat University hospitals of Marseille, southeastern France. The 11\ncases were 10 men and a woman. Their age was 57 plus or minus 11\nyears. One patient died 2 months after the onset of hepatitis. None of\nthe cases traveled abroad during the three months before the disease\nonset. Consumption of pig liver sausage was documented in 6 of 9\npatients that could be interviewed. Noteworthy, anti-HEV IgM could be\ndetected in the serum from the wife of 2 of the cases that ate\nuncooked pig liver sausage. Both women ate the same sausage as their\nhusbands. In one of the women, ALT level was 165 UI/l; no clinical\nsymptom was noted.\n\nEight of these 11 hepatitis E cases occurred from 24 Feb 2011. From\nthis date, the number of hepatitis E cases diagnosed in our lab\nsignificantly increased. This was detected by EPIMIC, a home-made\nalert and surveillance epidemiologic tool that analyses in real-time\nthe number of clinical samples and positive diagnosis in our\nmicrobiology lab. The alert threshold is the mean value of historical\ndata plus 2 standard deviations (SD). Starting from 24 Feb 2011, the\nnumber of serum samples tested and of those testing positive for\nanti-HEV IgM were above the threshold. Indeed, 54 sera were tested\n(mean value, 22; 2 SD, 30), and at least 5 of them tested positive for\nanti-HEV IgM (Adaltis assay) (mean value, 1; 2 SD, 3). Concurrently,\nthe number of PCR-documented hepatitis E was between 1 and 3 per week,\nwhereas the mean value is 0.4 based on historical data.\n\nIn developed industrialized countries, it was thought until recently\nthat hepatitis E was related to travel in tropical or sub-tropical\ncountries, where HEV infection is hyper-endemic. Nevertheless, it\nturns out that most cases are autochthonous, occurring in patients who\nhave not traveled abroad over the last 2-9 weeks (incubation period of\nthe disease). In France, more than 200 indigenous cases are reported\neach year. Most of them were diagnosed in the southern region, where\nthe prevalence of anti-HEV IgG in blood donors is higher than in the\nNorth (8-16.6 percent versus 3.4 percent).\n\nIt has been clearly shown in developed industrialized countries that\npigs (and boars) are reservoirs of the virus. Acute hepatitis E has\nbeen diagnosed in our lab in persons who consumed uncooked pig liver\nsausages, which are widely eaten in southeastern France. These\nsausages are good candidates for the transmission of hepatitis E\nbecause they are made with pig liver (the site of viral\nmultiplication), are not cooked during the manufacturing process, and\nare often eaten uncooked. We reported in 2009 on 8 hepatitis E among\npatients who ate pig liver sausage [see: ProMED-mail post archived as:\nHepatitis E - France: (Marseille) pig liver sausage 20090917.3267]. A\ncase-control study conducted in 3 different families revealed that\nacute or recent hepatitis E were significantly associated with\nconsumption of uncooked pig liver sausage. In addition, genetic links\nwere found between viral sequences recovered from sausages and those\nrecovered from patients.\n\nSubsequently to the notification of these cases, French health\nauthorities compelled producers of pig liver sausages to indicate on\nthe label of the products that they need to be cooked thoroughly.\nIndeed, it was shown that cooking pieces of liver containing HEV\nlimits their infectivity.\n\nThe mortality of symptomatic cases of hepatitis E is 1 to 4 percent;\nfatal outcome occurs mostly among people who already have chronic\nliver disease. Moreover, it appears that the infection can progress\ntowards chronic hepatitis among severely immunocompromized persons, as\nobserved in kidney or liver transplant recipients and in persons\ninfected with HIV. The proportion of asymptomatic HEV infections\nremains unknown to date.\n\n--\nPhilippe Colson PharmD PhD\nP\u00f4le des Maladies Infectieuses et Tropicales Clinique et\nBiologique,\nFederation de Bacteriologie-Hygiene-Virologie,\nCentre Hospitalo-Universitaire Timone, AP-HM,\nURMITE CNRS UMR 6236 IRD 198\nFacultes de Medecine et de Pharmacie\nUniversite de la Mediterranee\n<philippe.colson@ap-hm.fr>\nand\nRene Gerolami MD PhD\nService d'Hepato-Gastro-Enterologie\nCentre Hospitalo-Universitaire Conception\n147 boulevard Baille, 13385 Marseille CEDEX 05, France\n<rene.gerolami@ap-hm.fr>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Drs Philippe Colson and Rene Gerolami for sharing\nwith us and our readers this account of their current investigations\nof hepatitis E virus infection in southeastern France.\n\nTo put the clinical investigation of of Drs Colson and Gerolami in\ncontext, the following are some extracts from the WHO Fact sheet\n(http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs280/en/index.html):\n\n'Hepatitis E was not recognized as a distinct human disease until\n1980. Hepatitis E is caused by infection with hepatitis E virus (HEV),\na non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus. HEV is\ntransmitted via the faecal-oral route.\n\n'Hepatitis E has been considered a waterborne disease, and\ncontaminated water or food supplies have been implicated in major\noutbreaks. Consumption of faecally contaminated drinking water has\ngiven rise to epidemics, and the ingestion of raw or uncooked\nshellfish has been the source of sporadic cases in endemic areas.\nThere is a possibility of zoonotic spread of the virus, since several\nnon-human primates, pigs, cows, sheep, goats and rodents are\nsusceptible to infection. The risk factors for HEV infection are\nrelated poor sanitation in large areas of the world, and HEV shedding\nin faeces. Person-to-person transmission is uncommon. There has been\nno evidence for sexual transmission or for transmission by\ntransfusion. The highest rates of infection occur in regions where low\nstandards of sanitation promote the transmission of the virus.\nEpidemics of hepatitis E have been reported in Central and South-East\nAsia, North and West Africa, and in Mexico, especially where faecal\ncontamination of drinking water is common. However, sporadic cases of\nhepatitis E have also been reported elsewhere and serological surveys\nsuggest a global distribution of strains of hepatitis E of low\npathogenicity. In general, hepatitis E is a self-limiting viral\ninfection followed by recovery. Prolonged viraemia or faecal shedding\nare unusual and chronic infection does not occur.\n\n'The incubation period following exposure to HEV ranges from 3 to 8\nweeks, with a mean of 40 days. The period of communicability is\nunknown. There are no chronic infections reported.\n\n'Hepatitis E virus causes acute sporadic and epidemic viral\nhepatitis. Symptomatic HEV infection is most common in young adults\naged 15-40 years. Although HEV infection is frequent in children, it\nis mostly asymptomatic or causes a very mild illness without jaundice\n(anicteric) that goes undiagnosed.\n\n'Typical signs and symptoms of hepatitis include jaundice (yellow\ndiscoloration of the skin and sclera of the eyes, dark urine and pale\nstools), anorexia (loss of appetite), an enlarged, tender liver\n(hepatomegaly), abdominal pain and tenderness, nausea and vomiting,\nand fever, although the disease may range in severity from subclinical\nto fulminant.\n\n'Since cases of hepatitis E are not clinically distinguishable from\nother types of acute viral hepatitis, diagnosis is made by blood tests\nwhich detect elevated antibody levels of specific antibodies to\nhepatitis E in the body or by or by reverse transcriptase polymerase\nchain reaction (RT-PCR). Unfortunately, such tests are not widely\navailable.\n\n'Hepatitis E should be suspected in outbreaks of waterborne hepatitis\noccurring in developing countries, especially if the disease is more\nsevere in pregnant women, or if hepatitis A has been excluded. If\nlaboratory tests are not available, epidemiologic evidence can help in\nestablishing a diagnosis. (As is demonstrated by Drs Colson and\nGerolami above).\n\n'As no specific therapy is capable of altering the course of acute\nhepatitis E infection, prevention is the most effective approach\nagainst the disease. Hospitalization is required for fulminant\nhepatitis and should be considered for infected pregnant women.'\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of France is available at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/00Fc. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Facultes de Medecine et de Pharmacie\nUniversite de la Mediterranee\n<philippe.colson@ap-hm.fr>\nand\nRene Gerolami MD PhD\nService d'Hepato-Gastro-Enterologie\nCentre Hospitalo-Universitaire Conception\n147 boulevard Baille, 13385 Marseille CEDEX 05, France\n<rene.gerolami@ap-hm.fr>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Drs Philippe Colson and Rene Gerolami for sharing\nwith us and our readers this account of their current investigations\nof hepatitis E virus infection in southeastern France. \n\n--\nPhilippe Colson PharmD PhD\nP\u00f4le des Maladies Infectieuses et Tropicales Clinique et\nBiologique,\nFederation de Bacteriologie-Hygiene-Virologie,\nCentre Hospitalo-Universitaire Timone, AP-HM,\nURMITE CNRS UMR 6236 IRD 198\n \n\n'Typical signs and symptoms of hepatitis include jaundice (yellow\ndiscoloration of the skin and sclera of the eyes, dark urine and pale\nstools), anorexia (loss of appetite), an enlarged, tender liver\n(hepatomegaly), abdominal pain and tenderness, nausea and vomiting,\nand fever, although the disease may range in severity from subclinical\nto fulminant. The following 2 comments make it clear that\nthis information is incorrect. - Mod.CP]\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Wed 27 Oct 2010\nFrom: Gregor Caspari <g.caspari@ladr.de>\n\n\nThere are several genotypes of hepatitis E virus [HEV]. Genotype 1\nand 2 infect humans, genotype 3 mainly swine. Infection with genotype\n3 among swine is worldwide, independent of prevalence of hepatitis E\nvirus infection in humans in the respective region. Transmission\nbetween swine is likely to be faecal-oral. Uninfected swine are\ninfected in the presence of infected swine within weeks. Prevalence\ndepends upon the region of the world and upon the age of swine.\nAntibody prevalence at the age of 4 months is 50 to 90 percent. RNA\nprevalence in serum and faeces is between 5 and 55 percent and is\nhighest at the age of 2 to 4 months.\n\nThis genotype 3 is the one which is found in so-called autochthonous\ntransmissions. How the virus is transmitted from swine to humans is\nnot clear. In France, a surgeon was infected who trained his surgical\ntechnique on swine (Colson et al. 2007). Some Japanese publications\nreported transmission by uncooked or undercooked liver or meat from\nswine, boar or venison (Matsuda et al. 2003, Tei et al. 2003, Yazaki\net al. 2003, Tamada et al. 2004, Masuda et al. 2005). Infection was\nconfirmed epidemiologically by disease of persons who ate or by\ndemonstration of virus in the meat not eaten (Tei et al. 2003, Li et\nal. 2005). Yazaki et al. (2003) found HEV RNA in 7 of 363 swine\nlivers bought in grocery stores, Feagins et al. 2007 in 14 of 127\nlivers bought in the US. Two out of 3 of these RNA positive livers\nwere infectious when fed to naive swine. Recently, an epidemic in\nItaly was published apparently caused by locally produced sausages.\n\nAs there is a viraemic phase in hepatitis E virus infection, the\nvirus may be transmitted by blood. There are at least 6 documented\ntransmissions by blood transfusion; there are, furthermore,\ndocumented transmissions by transplantation. The risk for plasma\nproducts is unclear as there is no reason to assume that the virus is\ninactivated by one of the current virus inactivation methods, i.e.\nthe solvent detergent procedure (the method acts on the virus\nenvelope, and hepatitis E virus is not enveloped).\n\nMost infections may go unnoticed because either HEV infection is not\nsuspected and not tested for and/or genotype 3 may cause a milder\nform of disease in humans. Seroprevalence studies with more recent\ntests show a seroprevalence around 10 percent and more.\n\n--\nPriv.-Doz. Dr. med. habil. Gregor Caspari\nLADR GmbH MVZ Berlin\nAlt-Moabit 91a\n10559 Berlin\nGERMANY\n<g.caspari@ladr.de>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 27 Oct 2010\nFrom: Thomas Kreil < thomas_kreil@baxter.com>\n\n\nI'd like to draw to attention to a recent summary of hepatitis E\nvirus (HEV) transfusion transmissions. Such events were initially\nreported from particularly Japan, yet more recently also from e.g.\nGermany (see below). More complete information is available from\nPubMed; interested readers should use the search phrase 'HEV\ntransfusion transmission'.\n\nHepatitis E virus infection: a paradigm shift?] [In German]\n\nBy Pischke S, Potthoff A, Hauroder B, Schlue J, Manns MP, Cornberg M,\nWedemeyer H. At: Gastroenterologie, Medizinische Hochschule Hannover.\nReference: Dtsch Med Wochenschr. 2010 Jun;135(22):1129-33. Epub 2010 May 25.\n\nAbstract: Hepatitis E is an infectious disease caused by the\nhepatitis E virus (HEV). Hepatitis E is mainly a self-limiting\ntravel-associated disease without chronic evolution. In recent years,\nan increasing number of autochthonous HEV-infections has been\ndescribed in industrialized countries. HEV-infections frequently take\na mild clinical silent course of disease in immunocompetent\nindividuals, and thus HEV infection is largely under-diagnosed.\nTherefore, the anti-HEV-prevalence is much higher than anticipated\nwith 2-20 percent in Western Europe.\n\nHEV genotype 3 infections must be considered as zoonotic infections,\nwith several animals, including swine, serving as reservoirs. Cases\nof HEV-transmissions by blood transfusion were described not only in\nAsia but also in France and the UK. HEV-infections may take severe\ncourses in pregnant women and patients with chronic liver diseases,\nsometimes leading to acute liver failure. In addition, several\ncentres described cases of progressive chronic HEV-infection in organ\ntransplant recipients and HIV-positive patients during the last 2\nyears. In this review, we summarize the current state-of-the-art on\nthe knowledge of HEV-infections in industrialised countries.\n\n--\nThomas R. Kreil, Ph.D.\nAssociate Professor of Virology\nSenior Director Viral Vaccines & Global Pathogen Safety\nBaxter BioScience\nBenatzkygasse 2-6,\nA-1221 Vienna, Austria\n<thomas_kreil@baxter.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail is indebted to Gregor Caspari and Thomas R. Kreil for\nprovision of this information which sets the record straight and\nextends our understanding of the epidemiology of hepatitis E. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[In the preceding ProMED-mail post, the moderator (citing the WHO\nHepatitis E Fact sheet\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs280/en/index.html>)\ncommented that there is no evidence for transmission of hepatitis E\nvirus by transfusion. The risk for plasma\nproducts is unclear as there is no reason to assume that the virus is\ninactivated by one of the current virus inactivation methods, i.e.\nthe solvent detergent procedure (the method acts on the virus\nenvelope, and hepatitis E virus is not enveloped). There are at least 6 documented\ntransmissions by blood transfusion; there are, furthermore,\ndocumented transmissions by transplantation. HEV-infections may take severe\ncourses in pregnant women and patients with chronic liver diseases,\nsometimes leading to acute liver failure. In recent years,\nan increasing number of autochthonous HEV-infections has been\ndescribed in industrialized countries. More complete information is available from\nPubMed; interested readers should use the search phrase 'HEV\ntransfusion transmission'. Cases\nof HEV-transmissions by blood transfusion were described not only in\nAsia but also in France and the UK. 'In other parts of the world it usually affects the young.\nHowever in the cases being seen in the UK, it is the middle aged and\nelderly, particularly men.' The team\nconcluded that there was no epidemiological link between the cases or\nan associated link with eating or handling pork. Although we are\naware of a number of hepatitis E cases in the UK the majority are\nacquired outside the UK or related to travel to endemic countries.'\nIt is acknowledged that pigs and pork can harbour [hepatitis E virus]\nand that this may be the cause of the disease in cases where there\nhas not been any foreign travel, according to the HPA website.\n\nDr Dalton said those with existing liver conditions are most at risk\nand advised people to take care when preparing pork. Medics have told the\nfamily it is unclear whether he caught the virus because of exposure\nto the pig farm or through consuming infected pork.\n\nThe HPA website said there were 178 cases of hepatitis E in Britain\nin 2008 and 179 in 2009. Most people clear the infection without\ntreatment, however people with weakened immune systems or liver\ndisease may need closer observation, it said. There is no vaccine\nagainst hepatitis E [virus infection]. In 2008, 4 people in Britain\nfell ill with the virus after a world cruise. Infected shellfish were\nfound to be the cause.\n\n--\nCommunicated by a correspondent\nwho has requested anonymity\n\n[Hepatitis E was not recognized as a distinct human disease until\n1980. Hepatitis E is caused by infection with hepatitis E virus\n(HEV), a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus.\nAlthough man is considered the natural host for HEV, antibodies to\nHEV or closely related viruses have been detected in primates and\nseveral other animal species.\n\nHEV is transmitted via the faecal-oral route. Hepatitis E is a mostly\na waterborne disease, and contaminated water or food supplies have\nbeen implicated in major outbreaks. Consumption of faecally\ncontaminated drinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the\ningestion of raw or uncooked shellfish has been the source of\nsporadic cases in endemic areas. There is a possibility of zoonotic\nspread of the virus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows,\nsheep, goats and rodents are susceptible to infection.\nPerson-to-person transmission is uncommon. There is no evidence for\nsexual transmission or for transmission by transfusion. The highest\nrates of infection occur in regions where low standards of\nsanitation. However, sporadic cases of hepatitis E have also been\nreported elsewhere.\n\nIn general, hepatitis E is a self-limiting viral infection followed\nby recovery. Prolonged viraemia or faecal shedding are unusual and\nchronic infection does not occur. Occasionally, a fulminant form of\nhepatitis develops, with overall patient population mortality rates\nranging between 0.5 - 4.0 percent. The incubation period following\nexposure to HEV ranges from 3 to 8 weeks, with a mean of 40 days. The\nperiod of communicability is unknown. There are no chronic infections\nreported. Typical signs and symptoms of hepatitis include jaundice\n(yellow discoloration of the skin and sclera of the eyes, dark urine\nand pale stools), anorexia (loss of appetite), an enlarged, tender\nliver (hepatomegaly), abdominal pain and tenderness, nausea and\nvomiting, and fever, although the disease may range in severity from\nsubclinical to fulminant.\n\nIt has recently been shown that HEV is present in both domestic pigs\nand wild boar in various parts of Europe and the high genetic\nsimilarity between HEV isolates from pigs and humans confirm previous\ninferences of possible zoonotic transmission of HEV.\n\nSee also: 'Detection and characterization of infectious Hepatitis E\nvirus from commercial pig livers sold in local grocery stores in the\nUSA'. Until now, it has been assumed that human cases in\nGermany were mostly a result of travels to Asia and Africa, where this\ndisease is more common.\n\nRecent studies by the Federal Institute for Risk Assessment (BfR) and\nother research institutes indicate that, on average, 15 percent of\nwild boars hunted in Germany carry the hepatitis E virus. However, it\nis not clear so far whether these viruses can be transmitted directly\nto humans.\n\nFor protection from infection with the hepatitis E virus, BfR\nrecommends that consumers such as hunters should strictly keep\nsanitary conditions during carving up and that the meat should always\nbe properly cooked before consumption. Primary references are\navailable on request.\n\n- Only one autochthonous case (in 1999) of hepatitis E was reported\nduring the period from 1994 to 2000, all others were either imported\nor source unknown.\n- 10 autochthonous cases had been reported as of 2006.\n- 186 cases were reported during 1996 to 2003, including 17\nautochthonous cases.\n- 100 confirmed and presumed indigenous infections were reported in\n2005 (30.4 percent of total cases, 70 percent above age 55 years).\n- 181 cases were confirmed during January to June 2005, including 25\nautochthonous cases.\n- 21 autochthonous cases were documented in southwestern England\nduring a 7-year period (2007 publication); 28 in Cornwall and Devon\nduring 2005 to 2006.\n- A series of 24 cases of non-travel associated hepatitis E infection\nwas treated at a hospital in south Wales during a 25-month period\n(2010 publication).\n- 13 cases were confirmed in South Hampshire during a 13-month period\n(2005 to 2006).\n\nPrevalence surveys\n------------------\n- 5 percent to 35 percent of pigs on farms in the Yorkshire Humberside\narea (2008 publication)\n\nSeroprevalence surveys\n----------------------\n- 16 percent of blood donors, 13 percent of patients with chronic\nliver disease, and 25 percent in individuals over 60 years\n(southwestern England, 2008 publication)\n- 13 percent of persons in England (1991 to 2004)\n- 3.9 percent (native-born) to 8.8 percent (foreign-born) of persons\nin inner city London (1996 publication)\n- 2.4 percent of farming industry workers (2009 publication).\n\nHuman infection by a porcine strain of hepatitis E virus has been documented.\n\nNotable outbreaks\n-----------------\n2008 - an outbreak (33 cases) was reported among passengers on a\nBritish round-the-world cruise ship.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. J Infect Dis.\n2010 Sep 15; 202(6): 825-34\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/full/10.1086/655898>\n\nBackground\n----------\nThe source and route of autochthonous hepatitis E virus (HEV)\ninfections are not clearly established in industrialized countries\ndespite evidence that it is a zoonosis in pigs. We investigated the\nrole of figatellu, a traditional pig liver sausage widely eaten in\nFrance and commonly consumed raw, as a source of HEV infection.\n\nMethods\n-------\nA case-control study was conducted of 3 patients who presented\nautochthonous hepatitis E and 15 members of their 3 different\nfamilies. Anti-HEV immunoglobulin G and immunoglobulin M antibody\ntesting was performed with commercial assays. HEV RNA was detected in\nserum samples of patients and in pig liver sausages by means of\nreal-time polymerase chain reaction and sequenced by means of in-house\nsequencing assays. Genetic links between HEV sequences were analyzed.\n\nResults\n-------\nAcute or recent HEV infection, defined by detection of anti-HEV\nimmunoglobulin M antibodies and/or HEV RNA, was observed in 7 of 13\nindividuals who ate raw figatellu and 0 of 5 individuals who did not\neat raw figatellu (P = .041). Moreover, HEV RNA of genotype 3 was\nrecovered from 7 of 12 figatelli purchased in supermarkets, and\nstatistically significant genetic links were found between these\nsequences and those recovered from patients who ate raw figatellu.\n\nConclusion\n----------\nOur findings strongly support the hypothesis of HEV infection through\ningestion of raw figatellu.\n\n--\nLt Col Per L Lausund DVM MPH\nNorwegian Defence Research Institute\nKjeller\nNorway\n<veterinary.surgeon@gmail.com>", "summary": "Tel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Professor Berger for providing these collated data\nand for the information illustrating that reporting rates for\nhepatitis E virus infection in the UK (England and Wales) are higher\nthan in other parts of Europe. USA: (TX) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=452638", "date": "2010-06-24 16:00:04", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E VIRUS - USA: (TEXAS) FATAL\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 22 Jun 2010\nSource: UPI (United Press International), US News [edited]\n<http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2010/06/22/Fatal-hepatitis-E-reported-in-Texas/UPI-86981277232652/>\n\n\nFatal hepatitis E reported in Texas\n-----------------------------------\nHealth officials say 2 cases of hepatitis E, thought rare in the\nUnited States, have been reported in Texas and blamed for one death.\nThe San Antonio, Texas, cases of hepatitis E, a viral liver\ninfection, usually considered a problem mostly in developing\ncountries, have gotten the attention of state and local health\nofficials, the San Antonio Express-News reported Tuesday [22 Jun\n2010]. One of the cases was a 21-year-old woman who died during a\nliver transplant, the other a 44-year-old nurse's aide who suffered\nsome liver damage from the disease, the newspaper said.\n\n'We couldn't figure out how they acquired it,' Roger Sanchez, senior\nepidemiologist with Metro Health, said at a public health meeting in\nAustin recently. '[Neither] of them had any (foreign) travel history.\nThey were previously healthy. Which begs the question -- how did they\nget it?' Hepatitis E is usually spread through contaminated food or water.\n\nSerious outbreaks of hepatitis E have taken place in Mexico, Asia,\nand Africa. Some US researchers say hepatitis E is more common in the\nUnited States than previously thought. What remains a mystery, they\nsay, is why some people get sick from the virus but most don't. 'It\nappears to be a relatively common infection. But clinical symptoms\nfollowing infection appear to be quite rare,' Mark Kuniholm, an\nepidemiologist at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York, said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E was not recognized as a distinct human disease until\n1980. Hepatitis E is caused by infection with hepatitis E virus\n(HEV), a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus.\nAlthough man is considered the natural host for HEV, antibodies to\nHEV or closely related viruses have been detected in primates and\nseveral other animal species.\n\nHEV is transmitted via the faecal-oral route. Hepatitis E is a\nwaterborne disease, and contaminated water or food supplies have been\nimplicated in major outbreaks. Consumption of faecally contaminated\ndrinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the ingestion of raw\nor uncooked shellfish has been the source of sporadic cases in\nendemic areas. There is a possibility of zoonotic spread of the\nvirus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows, sheep, goats,\nand rodents are susceptible to infection. The risk factors for HEV\ninfection are related to poor sanitation in large areas of the world,\nand HEV shedding in faeces. Person-to-person transmission is\nuncommon. There is no evidence for sexual transmission or for\ntransmission by transfusion.\n\nThe highest rates of infection occur in regions where low standards\nof sanitation promote the transmission of the virus. Epidemics of\nhepatitis E have been reported in Central and South-East Asia, North\nand West Africa, and in Mexico, especially where faecal contamination\nof drinking water is common. However, sporadic cases of hepatitis E\nhave also been reported elsewhere and serological surveys suggest a\nglobal distribution of strains of hepatitis E of low pathogenicity.\n\nFurther information can be obtained from the WHO fact sheet on hepatitis E at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs280/en/index.html>.\n\nIn general, hepatitis E is a self-limiting viral infection followed\nby recovery. Prolonged viraemia or faecal shedding are unusual and\nchronic infection does not occur. Occasionally, a fulminant form of\nhepatitis develops, with overall patient population mortality rates\nranging between 0.5 percent-4.0 percent. Fulminant hepatitis occurs\nmore frequently in pregnancy and regularly induces a mortality rate\nof 20 percent among pregnant women in the 3rd trimester. The immune\nsuppression accompanying liver transplantation may be been a factor\nin the hepatitis E associated fatality recorded in San Antonio. - Mod.CP]\n\n[San Antonio can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01z2>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 22 Jun 2010\n The San Antonio, Texas, cases of hepatitis E, a viral liver\ninfection, usually considered a problem mostly in developing\ncountries, have gotten the attention of state and local health\nofficials, the San Antonio Express-News reported Tuesday [22 Jun\n2010]. Epidemics of\nhepatitis E have been reported in Central and South-East Asia, North\nand West Africa, and in Mexico, especially where faecal contamination\nof drinking water is common. Consumption of faecally contaminated\ndrinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the ingestion of raw\nor uncooked shellfish has been the source of sporadic cases in\nendemic areas. However, sporadic cases of hepatitis E\nhave also been reported elsewhere and serological surveys suggest a\nglobal distribution of strains of hepatitis E of low pathogenicity. One of the cases was a 21-year-old woman who died during a\nliver transplant, the other a 44-year-old nurse's aide who suffered\nsome liver damage from the disease, the newspaper said. Hepatitis E is a\nwaterborne disease, and contaminated water or food supplies have been\nimplicated in major outbreaks. There is a possibility of zoonotic spread of the\nvirus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows, sheep, goats,\nand rodents are susceptible to infection. Fulminant hepatitis occurs\nmore frequently in pregnancy and regularly induces a mortality rate\nof 20 percent among pregnant women in the 3rd trimester. Occasionally, a fulminant form of\nhepatitis develops, with overall patient population mortality rates\nranging between 0.5 percent-4.0 percent. The\ndistrict health inspector, Mr Martin Eyura, said investigations carried out\nby the district health workers in Moroto Municipality confirmed that the\ndisease has broke out in the 4 suburbs of Police Barracks, Singila,\nNakapelimon, Junior Quarters, and in Matany Trading Centre outside the\nmunicipality a month ago before spreading to other areas.\n\n'We heard it had broken out in Kaabong District [Moroto District lies to\nthe south east of Kaabong District. - Mod.CP] but you know people here are\ncareless. They defecate anywhere, leaving the human waste to become a\nbreeding place for the disease.'\n\nThere are 9 cases from Singila, 7 from Nakapelimon, 5 from Junior Quarters,\nand another 7 from Matany Trading Centre admitted at Moroto Government\nHospital and the disease seems to be spreading fast,' the district health\ninspector, Martin Eyura, said. Reports at the hospital confirm that 28\npeople who have been admitted to the health unit, have been tested and\ndiscovered to have hepatitis E.\n\nThe nurses at the hospital, who preferred anonymity, said that 8 cases had\nfirst been registered but the numbers have since increased to 28. District\nleaders and health workers in Kaabong managed to fight diseases with good\nhygiene and sanitation unlike in Moroto where people are not using\npit-latrines, including market vendors who use a seasonal river, Nangololo\nin Moroto Municipality to ease themselves. Mr Eyura also attributed the\nsurge in hepatitis E cases to poor sanitation. 'The district health team is\nmoving door to door, surveilling and sensitising locals about the disease\nto help bring down the number of victims.\n\n'Hepatitis E is a viral disease that affects the liver and if it is not\ntreated well, it kills very fast,' he said, adding that most patients are\ncomplaining of headache, fever, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite,\nabdominal pain, diarrhoea, jaundice, heartburn, dark urine, and pain, which\nare all symptoms of the disease. Hepatitis E is a limiting disease that may\noccur after natural disasters because of consumption of faecally\ncontaminated water or food. It is caused by infection with the hepatitis E\nvirus, a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus. Although\nman is considered the natural host for hepatitis E virus, antibodies to\nhepatitis E virus or closely related viruses have been detected in primates\nand several other animal species. Drinking faecally contaminated water has\ngiven rise to epidemics, and consumption of raw or half-cooked shellfish\nhas been the source of sporadic cases in endemic areas.\n\nMr Eyuru maintains that people most at risk of the disease are 15-40 year\nolds, including pregnant women and people living with HIV/AIDS. He adds\nthat the disease can be prevented if everyone disposes of their waste\nproperly, and appeals to local district leaders to play their role in\nhelping the health teams ensure that people are sensitised about the\ndisease to avoid further spread.\n\nThe deputy resident district commissioner, Mr Bob Opio, also urged the\nresidents to make use of pit latrines and observe hygiene and sanitation to\nsave their lives. 'The government is committed to making sure that people\nare protected from diseases. but we must also do our part.'\n\n[byline: David Mafabi]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Moroto District is a district in north eastern Uganda. Consumption of faecally contaminated\ndrinking water has given rise to epidemics, and the ingestion of raw or\nuncooked shellfish has been another source of sporadic cases in endemic\nareas. There is a possibility of zoonotic spread of the virus, since\nseveral non-human primates, pigs, cows, sheep, goats, and rodents are\nsusceptible to infection.\n\nThe risk factors for hepatitis E virus infection are related to poor\nsanitation in large areas of the world. In Uganda past outbreaks have often\noccurred in camps for IDPs (internally displaced persons) or refugees from\nelsewhere. Person-to-person transmission is uncommon. There is no evidence\nfor sexual transmission.\n\nIn general, hepatitis E is a self-limiting viral infection followed by\nrecovery. 'We\nhave been hit by an increasing number of patients and deaths in the\ndistrict,' he said.\n\nHepatitis E is a viral infection that is transmitted through drinking\nwater or eating contaminated food. The virus is found in the stool of\ninfected persons or animals.\n\nIn 2007, there was an outbreak of hepatitis E in northern Uganda,\nkilling 169 people and infecting over 10 000. In Karamoja, the\ndisease was first diagnosed in Kaabong district in August 2009 with a\nfew cases in the town. However, the last few weeks have seen a\nspillover to neighbouring sub-counties due to poor sanitation. 'The\nmost affected sub-counties are Kaabong rural and Sidok, where the\nhealth authorities are registering at least 4 cases daily. Some are\ntreated and discharged,' said Lochiyo. He attributed the spread of\nthe disease to the local cultural belief, which discourages latrine usage.\n\n'The Karimojong [an ethnic group of agro-pastoral herders living\nmainly in the north-east of Uganda] defecate in river beds that are\nalso places where they scoop water to drink or for domestic use,' he\nsaid. The health officer noted that latrine coverage in Kaabong\ndistrict stands at only 2 percent. He urged residents to construct\nlatrines and use them since the disease is spread through contact\nwith feacal matter. France: (Marseille) pig liver sausage\n20090917.3267\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe following background data on hepatitis E in France were abstracted\nfrom the Gideon database.\n\nIncidence\n---------\n- 46 cases were confirmed during 2002 to 2004 -- including 16 imported cases.\n- 62 cases were confirmed in southwestern France during 2003 to 2007.\n- 369 cases were reported during 2006 to 2008: 264 autochthonous, 51\nimported and 54 unclassified.\n\nDuring 2001 to 2002, autochthonous infection was documented in 2.72\npercent of acute hepatitis patients in the Midi Pyrenees area.\n\nA case of transfusion-related hepatitis E infection was reported in 2006\n\nRisk factors for hepatitis E in France have included water consumption\nfrom a personal water supply, consumption of uncooked shellfish, and\nthe recent acquisition of a pet pig.\n\nPrevalence surveys\n------------------\n- 2.5 percent of wild boar (_Sus scrofa_) livers in southeastern\nFrance (2009 publication)\n\nSeroprevalence surveys\n----------------------\n- 2.6 percent of pregnant women\n- 3.2 percent of blood donors (2007 publication)\n- 16.6 percent of blood donors in southwestern France (2008 publication)\n- 40 percent of piglets in southern France (2009 publication)\n\nNotable outbreaks\n-----------------\n- 1983 to 1984 -- outbreaks of presumed hepatitis E infection were\nreported among French soldiers in Chad.\n2008 (publication year) -- an outbreak (2 cases) in Southern France\nwas related to ingestion of raw pig meat.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[Professor Berger has indicated that he will supply primary references\nfor these data on request. - Figatelli are widely consumed\nin France, and they are good candidates for hepatitis E virus (HEV)\ntransmission because they are made with pig liver and are commonly\neaten raw.\n\nA case-control study revealed that acute or recent HEV infection was\nsignificantly linked with consumption of raw figatellu. Moreover,\ngenotype 3 HEV sequences were recovered from 7 figatelli purchased in\nsupermarkets in southeastern France, and genetic links were found\nbetween these sequences and those recovered from patients who ate raw\nfigatellu. In each case, the delay between figatellu consumption and\nhepatitis onset was compatible with the incubation period of hepatitis\nE.\n\nAutochthonous hepatitis E is an emerging disease in industrialized\ncountries, but the source and route of HEV infections are not known in\nmost cases despite increasing evidence that it is a zoonosis with pigs\nas reservoirs.\n\nIn France, more than 100 autochthonous cases are notified per year.\nMost of them have occurred in the South, where HEV seroprevalence was\nfound to be higher than in the North (16.6 percent versus 3.4 percent)\nand where 7 fatal cases have been reported. Our findings have been\nnotified to the French public health authorities, and since May 2009,\nan official policy compels the manufacturers of pig liver sausages to\nrecommend cooking these sausages thoroughly. Indeed, it has been shown\nthat cooking HEV-containing food products limits their ability to\ntransmit infectious HEV.\n\n--\nPhilippe Colson PharmD PhD\nPole des Maladies Infectieuses et Tropicales Clinique et Biologique,\nFederation de Bacteriologie-Hygiene-Virologie,\nCentre Hospitalo-Universitaire Timone, AP-HM,\n264, rue Saint-Pierre 13385 Marseille cedex 5, France\n<philippe.colson@ap-hm.fr>\n&\nRene Gerolami MD PhD\nService d'Hepato-Gastro-Enterologie\nCentre Hospitalo-Universitaire Conception\n147 boulevard Baille, 13385 Marseille CEDEX 05, France\n<rene.gerolami@ap-hm.fr>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Drs Colson and Gerolami for drawing attention to\nthis unique example of food-borne transmission of hepatitis E virus\n(HEV) infection. We regret an inadvertent delay in posting this\nmeticulous report.\n\nAlthough humans have been considered the natural host for HEV,\nantibodies to HEV or closely related viruses have been detected in\nprimates and several other animal species, domestic pigs in particular.\n\nHEV is normally considered to be transmitted via the faecal-oral\nroute, and hepatitis E is usually regarded as a waterborne disease.\nConsumption of faecally contaminated drinking water has been the cause\nof most epidemics, but the ingestion of raw or uncooked shellfish has\nbeen the source of sporadic cases in endemic areas. To this can now be\nadded the consumption of raw pig liver sausages (figatellu). Indeed,\nany food product derived from pig liver should not be consumed\nuncooked. - Mod.CP]\n\n[See photo of figatelli at:\n<http://iledebeaute.i.l.pic.centerblog.net/p6fd1zci.jpg>\n- Mod.JW]", "summary": "\n\n--\nPhilippe Colson PharmD PhD\nPole des Maladies Infectieuses et Tropicales Clinique et Biologique,\nFederation de Bacteriologie-Hygiene-Virologie,\nCentre Hospitalo-Universitaire Timone, AP-HM,\n264, rue Saint-Pierre 13385 Marseille cedex 5, France\n<philippe.colson@ap-hm.fr>\n&\n Rene Gerolami MD PhD\nService d'Hepato-Gastro-Enterologie\nCentre Hospitalo-Universitaire Conception\n147 boulevard Baille, 13385 Marseille CEDEX 05, France\n<rene.gerolami@ap-hm.fr>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Drs Colson and Gerolami for drawing attention to\nthis unique example of food-borne transmission of hepatitis E virus\n(HEV) infection. Most\nwere reported in the village health centres of Lukung, Amida, Padibe,\nLayamu, and Kitgum town, according to Sylvester Opira, chairman of\nthe hepatitis E control taskforce in Kitgum.\n\n'New cases of infection are being received at health centres, with\nwomen and children ranking high,' Opira told IRIN in Kitgum. Poor\nsanitation in areas of return for IDPs and the rains had contributed\nto the spread of the disease. Few people, Opira said, had latrines in\ntheir homes while some were drinking water from unprotected sources,\nwhich could be contaminated. 'People with no latrines in their homes\nwill be arrested and forced to sink latrines,' he added.\n\nUp to 156 people have so far died of hepatitis E in Kitgum since 2007\nwhen the disease was first reported. Another 9912 people have been\ninfected. Tony Toolit, the Kitgum district secretary for health, told\nIRIN the main problem was lack of clean water for people returning to\nvillages. 'In some places, people are drinking water from ponds and\nstreams, [thus] spreading the infection,' he said. Toolit said safe\nwater and latrine coverage in Kitgum was only about 40 percent. There\nwas, therefore, a need to scale up prevention messages, provide clean\nwater and assist IDPs with latrine construction materials.\n\nHepatitis E is a viral disease spread [via] the faecal-oral route.\nOutbreaks tend to be linked to contaminated water or food supplies.\nMortality rates are generally low, ranging from 0.5 to 4.0 percent.\nBut among pregnant women in their 3rd trimester this rate can rise to\n20 percent.\n\nSee also: Hepatitis E outbreak on the rise in Kitgum at\n<http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=78844>.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Hepatitis E was not recognized as a distinct human disease until\n1980. Hepatitis E is caused by infection with hepatitis E virus, a\nnon-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus. Although\nman is considered the natural host for HEV, antibodies to HEV or\nclosely related viruses have been detected in primates and several\nother animal species. Hepatitis E virus is transmitted via the\nfaecal-oral route. Hepatitis E is a waterborne disease, and\ncontaminated water or food supplies have been implicated in major\noutbreaks. There is a possibility also of zoonotic spread of the\nvirus, since several non-human primates, pigs, cows, sheep, goats,\nand rodents are susceptible to infection. The risk factors for\nhepatitis E virus infection are related to poor sanitation in large\nareas of the world, and shedding of the virus in faeces.\nPerson-to-person transmission is uncommon. There is no evidence for\nsexual transmission or for transmission by transfusion. The highest\nrates of infection occur in regions where low standards of sanitation\npromote the transmission of the virus. However, sporadic cases of\nhepatitis E have also been reported elsewhere and serological surveys\nsuggest a global distribution of strains of hepatitis E of low\npathogenicity. Many people\nfeared that the deadly Ebola virus that struck the district in August\n[2008] killing 22 people was back. According to district\nhealth officer, Dr William Sikyewunda, blood samples have been sent to the\nUganda Virus Research Institute in Entebbe for examination. But as the\npublic waits for results, reports of this new attack bring into question\nsafety and measures instituted to prevent another possible epidemic,\nconsidering that since hepatitis E was first reported in Kitgum District in\nOctober last year [2007], it has claimed 150 lives and affected 9000 people.\n\nThe major focus in checking the spread of hepatitis, which according to the\nMinistry of Health originated from South Sudan and found its way to\nnorthern Uganda through the cross-border movements of the residents, lies\nin hygiene. The Ministry says hepatitis E was able to hibernate and develop\nbecause of the despicable sanitary conditions in most displaced people's\nand satellite camps in the north. Disposal of human waste in the open,\ncharacteristic of camps is the perfect breeding ground for this disease,\nnoting that it places water and food at great risk of contamination.\n\nWith high death figures in the past and new cases being reported, one would\nsuppose that all measures are being taken to avoid an escalation of the\nproblem in the north and now the west. But if the word of Dr Dawson\nMbulamberi, the assistant commissioner at the Ministry of Health is\nanything to go by, gloom awaits. He says improving sanitation in camps is a\ntough call, though he quips that the ministry is doing its best to better\nconditions.\n\nThe same view is supported by the Pader [district] deputy RDC [resident\ndistrict commissioner], Mr Charles Kurua, who observes that since residents\ncontinue to live in unhealthy conditions, they continue to be vulnerable to\ndiseases like hepatitis E and cholera. Dr Charles Oyoo, the officer in\ncharge of the Padibe health centre in Kitgum District, says travellers must\nbe checked if the disease is to be contained.\n\nHowever, when hepatitis E was reported in October last year [2007], it did\nnot spread beyond 5 districts in northern Uganda. Dr Oyoo says the\nsituation in Gulu has improved due to the sensitisation of the people.\n'Almost every member of the population has received adequate information\nabout hepatitis E but then the behavioural component is what is very\ndifficult to control. There is continued communal hand washing,[and]\nsharing food remains our biggest challenge,' he said.\n\nInertia or fear to change, Dr Oyoo notes, may jeopardise the quest to check\nspread of hepatitis E, which destroys the liver. 'There are still\nre-infections. This means whichever information they got, they have not put\nit in practice and yet these are adults. Isolation cannot work because by\nthe time the person develops the symptoms, she/he may have interacted many\npeople.' He adds, 'The sanitation standards are still poor. As people\nreturn home, we've emphasised that the 1st thing they should construct are\nlatrines. But that has not been adequately addressed.'\n\nThe private sector and NGOs have also jumped into the fray to help combat\nthe spread of the disease. According to the outgoing Oxfam public health\nmanager, Ms Julie Cailet, the agency has chlorinated more than 200\nboreholes, distributed up to 50 000 jerrycans, and constructed more than\n700 latrines in the north. Oxfam has also gone to 45 schools to preach on\nbehaviour change.\n\nTo ensure that the north is free of this latest hepatitis outbreak, Dr Oyoo\nsays authorities have discouraged storage of drinking water in pots,\nencouraged children to wash their hands after using the latrine, eating hot\nfood, digging soil and covering human waste. Just in case the disease\nreturns, health staffing may be a major undoing. Padibe health centre, for\nexample, which receives about 200 patients daily, has only 14 staff.\n\nActivists may also have to deal with the question of cultural practices.\nPeople have resorted to traditional healers and in some families; they\nprefer to hide patients for fear of stigmatisation. Bundibugyo can learn a\nlesson from northern Uganda, but even then, if the disease spreads,\nquestions still linger whether an epidemic can be contained.\n\n[byline: Edgar R Batte, Eve Mashoo]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[These press reports suggest that the hepatitis E outbreak in the displaced\npeople's camps in the north of Uganda has spread to the Bundibugyo District\nfurther south and west. This, however, is a reduction in the\ninfections from 90 cases reported the previous week. According to the\nMinistry of Health, the disease is receding. The ministry said the\ncumulative number of hepatitis [E] infections now stands at 8617.\n\nOnly one new death was reported in Lokung sub-county in the week,\nwhich brings the cumulative deaths to 127 in 41 weeks. 'On the whole,\nthe trend of the hepatitis E outbreak continues to recede in all the\nsub-counties of Kitgum district,' a statement from the ministry\nstated. Layamo sub-county had 15 of the new cases, while Agoro and\nPadibe reported 10 each. Kitgum Town Council had 6, Mucwini had 5,\nwhile Lagoro and Paloga reported 4 each. Madi Opei, Kitgum Matidi,\nand Namukora reported 2 cases each, while Lokung, Akwang, Omiya\nAnyima, and Amida reported one case each. The statement said Layamo,\nAgoro, Padibe, and Kitgum town council had registered the highest\nnumber of cases.\n\nThe disease, which is spread through consumption of food and fluids\ncontaminated with infected faecal matter, broke out in October last\nyear [2007]. The most affected were people living in camps for the\ninternally displaced and those returning to their villages after the\nLRA [Lord's Resistance Army] insurgency.\n\nThe disease's long incubation period had been responsible for its\nspread, according to the Minister of Health, Dr Stephen Mallinga. He\nsaid recently that the heavy rains in Kitgum had increased\ntransmission of the disease because people returning from camps had\nlimited safe drinking water. The problem was compounded by lack of\npit latrines, with people easing themselves in bushes from where the\nvirus found its way into the water sources. According to Mallinga,\nthere was need for the water ministry to sink more boreholes. He said\nthe Min Health was working with UNICEF (UN Children's Fund) and the\nWorld Health Organisation (WHO) to provide better services in the region.\n\n[Byline: Anne Mugisa)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Although the outbreak of hepatitis E infection in the Kitgum\ndistrict of Uganda may be beginning to decline, the number of new\ncases is substantial, bringing the overall total in the Kitgum\ndistrict to 8617. Hepatitis E has been ravaging parts of northern\nUganda since October 2007 and has so far killed 97, while the number\nof those infected has reached 5779, according to the latest update\nreport from the Ministry of Health.\n\nAccording to Health Minister Dr Stephen Mallinga, the majority of\nthose who have died are pregnant women. 'Because women have lower\nimmunity during pregnancy, cases of hepatitis E are severe and cause\nmore death among them,' he said, adding that the problem is\nexacerbated by some cultural beliefs that pregnant women should not\nuse latrines. As a result, most of the women will just dispose of\nfaeces in the open air, which is a good breeding ground for [i.e. the\nspread of] the hepatitis E virus.\n\nUnited Nations Children's Fund (Unicef) Country Representative Mr\nKeith McKenzie said the higher rate of death from hepatitis E among\npregnant women remains of grave concern. He said that most of the\npregnant women who succumb to hepatitis E are in their 3rd trimester;\nthis is usually the last phase of the pregnancy up to the time of\nbirth. 'This is double mortality because not only are the mothers\ndying but their unborn children too. We all need to play an active\nrole to contain the situation,' Mr McKenzie said. According to a\nWorld Health Organisation fact sheet on Hepatitis E\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs280/en/>, overall\nmortality rate from hepatitis E ranges between 0.5 to 4 percent, with\nmore cases registered among pregnant women. 'Fulminate hepatitis\noccurs more frequently in pregnancy and regularly induces a mortality\nrate of 20 percent among pregnant women in the 3rd trimester.'\n\nA person infected with hepatitis E develops fever, headache, general\nbody weakness, muscle pains and eventually develops yellow eyes and\npasses urine of a deep yellow colour.\n\nHepatitis E initially struck Kitgum District in October 2007, but has\nsince spread to the districts of Gulu, Pader and Yumbe.\n\nWhile it is not easy to get infected with hepatitis E, the appalling\nhygiene in the affected districts where many people displaced by the\nLord's Resistance Army insurgency live in squalid conditions in camps\nhas fueled the disease's spread. Dr Mallinga said in one camp for\ndisplaced people in Kitgum District, up to 15 000 people were sharing\none latrine of 6 stances. 'The major challenges are inadequate access\nto safe water, unhygienic disposal of faeces, poor personal and\ndomestic hygiene,' Dr Mallinga said, adding that bylaws should be\npassed at the district and subcounty levels to compel households to\ndig pit latrines.\n\nThe situation is made worse by the shortage of health workers,\ninadequate funding and limited participation of local authorities at\nthe grassroots level in enforcement of bylaws and ordinances that\npromote good health and sanitation. As a preventive measure, health\nexperts are urging pregnant women to attend antenatal services so\nthat early diagnosis can be made in case infection occurs.\n\nAn emergency plan to fight the hepatitis E epidemic in northern\nUganda has already been launched, and the Ministry of Health hopes it\nwill help eliminate the virus from the community. The UGX 10 billion\n[USD 6.2 million] will focus on teaching residents about proper\nhygiene, improvement of sanitation through construction of boreholes\nand pit latrines in internally displaced people's camps, and\nmonitoring infected people to ensure they are treated. WHO says there\nis no specific therapy for altering the course of acute hepatitis E\ninfection, and prevention is the most effective approach against the disease.\n\n[Byline: Evelyn Lirri]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The case count and fatality rate in this report are marginally lower\nthan those given in the preceding report from Kitgum on Fri 1 Aug\n2008. However, the above report provides added details regarding\nlocal customs and behavior that may be exacerbating the outbreak and\nincreasing the vulnerability of pregnant women. An earlier report\n(Hepatitis E virus - Uganda (02): (West Nile) 20080512.1612)\nsuggested, in addition, that the 40 percent increased blood volume of\nwomen in late stage pregnancy may be an additional factor in their\nlower resistance to hepatitis E virus infection.\n\nA map of Uganda showing the location of Kitgum, Gulu, Pader and Yumbo\nin the north can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/uganda_pol_2005.jpg>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 6 Aug 2008\n An earlier report\n(Hepatitis E virus - Uganda (02): (West Nile) 20080512.1612)\nsuggested, in addition, that the 40 percent increased blood volume of\nwomen in late stage pregnancy may be an additional factor in their\nlower resistance to hepatitis E virus infection. Another 6563 remain infected with the\ndeadly viral disease, which broke out in northern Uganda late last\nyear [2007]. Over the last week 9 people have died bringing the death\ntoll to 25 since 17 Jul 2008.\n\nThe WHO, which has been supporting the district's Hepatitis E Task\nForce, in its recent statements, said there is a drastic decline in\nthe infection rate in Kitgum, a report the authorities in the\ndistrict dispute. Authorities there say the district remains the\nworst-hit and the disease, which is spread by poor hygiene, has\nclaimed 50 lives in Madi Opei sub-county, Lamwo County, where the\noutbreak was first reported.\n\nThe director for Clinical Health Services in the Ministry of Health,\nDr Kenya Mugisha said the death toll now stands at 106. 'The cases of\ndeaths and new infections are almost half of what we have been\nregistering in the past and the situation is getting much better\nbecause of increased awareness, distribution of clean containers for\nwater collection and storage and other supplies, construction of more\npit latrines, among other interventions,' he said.\n\nKitgum chairman Komakech John Ogwok told journalists yesterday [12\nAug 2008] that the continued spread of hepatitis has forced the\ncouncil to enact bylaws aimed at controlling the disease. Some of\nthem include banning the use of water pots and drinking kwete, a\nlocal fermented drink believed to be a prime means of transmission.\n\nHepatitis E is an acute viral disease that can cause liver failure.\nThe virus is transmitted to humans through consumption of drink or\nfood contaminated with faecal matter. It can kill within a week if\nnot controlled in time.\n\nThe disease first struck Kitgum in October 2007, but has since spread\nto Gulu, Pader and Yumbe districts. Mr Ogwok, who is also the\nchairperson of the district Hepatitis Task Force, claimed jerricans\nand chlorine provided under the government/WHO emergency programme\nhave not helped to check the spread of the disease. The health\nworker-turned-politician also dismissed claims in the area that the\ndisease can spread through sexual intercourse. 'This disease has\nnothing to do with any one's sexual life,' he said. 'Having sex with\nan infected person does not lead to infection of the other person. It\nis a misconception by many people out there.' He warned that those\nwho resort to local herbs instead of going to health centres for\ntreatment risk succumbing to the disease.\n\nThe Ministry of Health recently allocated 25 million Ugandan\nshillings [approx. USD 15 325] to support sensitisation programmes in\nthe district but the money has not been sent to date, according to\nofficials. Meanwhile, the deputy RDC [resident district\ncommissioner], Mr Sylvester Opira, said efforts were under way to\narrest and prosecute residents who have refused to construct latrines\nin their homes. 'We are pleased that with the district-wide\nmobilisation carried out to fight the disease, a good number of homes\nnow have latrines though a few others are still hesitant to have\nthem. We shall soon start working on them,' said Mr Opira.\n\nAgoro border market, one of the busiest markets at the\nUganda-Southern Sudan border was closed recently due to lack of\nlatrines as a way of combating hepatitis E in the area.\n\n[Byline: James Eriku]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of fatalities has increased from 97 to 106 since 6 Aug\n2008 and the number of surviving cases from 5779 to 6563. 'More\ncases are being received in health units in villages and there is\nneed for urgent attention to check on the disease that is on the\nrise,' he told IRIN. Since 2007, the viral disease has infected up to\n8000 people in neighbouring Kitgum district alone, and killed 129.\nThe disease has since spread to the districts of Pader, Gulu,\nAdjumani, and Amuru.\n\nHepatitis E is transmitted mainly by drinking contaminated water or\neating contaminated food. Poor sanitation\nhas contributed to the spread of the disease, with some IDPs lacking\npit latrines and others drinking unsafe water from unprotected\nsources, leaving them prone to infection, Kurua said. 'Our people are\nliving under unhygienic conditions in IDP camps and areas of return\nin villages that leave them more vulnerable to diseases such as\nhepatitis E and cholera,' he said. 'If they [IDPs] keep on staying in\nthe camps, more would die from the diseases.'\n\nThe infected were being treated at Kalongo, the main hospital in the\ndistrict, as well as in health centres in Pader, Acholi Bur, Pajule,\nand Patongo areas. Kurua said the taskforce was being frustrated by a\nlack of adequate resources, making it hard for its members to reach\nall the communities living in Pader. He said efforts were underway to\ndrill boreholes in all resettlement areas to avoid outbreaks of\nsanitation-related diseases.\n\nAlfred Akena, a local leader in Pader, said the situation was\nworrying because in most of the villages IDPs are returning to do not\nhave adequate functional health centres. 'A number of parishes have\nnot been able to get health centres within their reach due to a\ncollaboration gap between the parish development committees and the\ndistrict, this is dangerous when we get outbreak of diseases,' he\nsaid. Moreover, Akena said, people in the neighbouring district of\nKotido also risk infection of hepatitis E following an influx of\nKarimojong people looking for food and water. There are cases of\nrelapse because some patients are failing to complete treatment. In\nthe same week (Epi week 35), 4 people succumbed to the disease. A\ncumulative total of 7727 cases and 121 deaths have been registered in\n17 sub counties in Kitgum district since the onset of the epidemic on\n25 Oct 2007. It should, however, be noted that there are deaths and\nhepatitis E cases that are not reported to health centres.\n\nAccording to the Branch Field Coordinator, Kitgum, Mr. Peter Opika\nOpoka, health assistants in all sub counties have been asked to\nfollow up and clarify the case definition. The increase in the number\nof deaths is attributed to late reporting to health facilities and\nconsumption of the local Herbs which add toxic materials to the\nalready infected liver. Mr. Opika says residents usually consume the\nlocal herbs in KWETE (Local Brew) and this causes re-infection.\n\nOf the 19 sub counties in Kitgum District, 17 have been affected. The\n2 sub counties of Palabek Kal and Palabek Ogili that have not been\naffected have in the past suffered cholera outbreaks but sanitation\nin the areas has reportedly improved, a reason they could have\nsurvived the Hepatitis E outbreak.\n\nA team from Ministry of Health is holding several meetings with\nstakeholders in Kitgum District to review strategies of fighting the\ndisease and coordinating resources. The team includes; one officer in\ncharge of Environmental Health, another in charge of social\nmobilization and the in-charge clinical medicine.\n\nUganda Red Cross Society (URCS) is continuing with interventions in\nAgoro Sub County, one of the worst affected sub counties in Kitgum\nDistrict, through provision of safe water. URCS is chlorinating water\nat 24 boreholes and as of 31 Aug 2008, 3 260 000 litres of water had\nbeen chlorinated.\n\nURCS is also conducting hygiene promotion through the village health\nteams and the Local council one chairman. This is being done through\nsensitization and clean-up campaigns; ensuring latrine cleaning and\nsafe water and food at household level.\n\nThe National Society is verifying village registers with the view of\ndistributing Jerry cans and soap to enhance hygiene and safe water\nstorage. IEC materials (Posters, Brochures and T-shirts) to create\nawareness on the prevention and control of Hepatitis E are also being\ndistributed throughout the district. The interventions have helped to\nscale down the rate of infections in Agoro.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[One hopes that the 21 percent decline in cases signals that the peak\nof the epidemic has passed. He added that\nover 6000 cases had been registered in the district since the\noutbreak began in October last year [2007].\n\nHe appealed to the leaders at the grassroots to mobilise and\nsensitise the communities on hygiene and sanitation in order to\ncontrol the spread of the disease. He said leaders have to ensure\nthat each household has a pit latrine and that the compounds and\nsurrounding areas are kept clean in accordance with public health regulations.\n\nThe head of the World Health Organisation (WHO) in Kitgum, Dr Charles\nOkot, said hepatitis E had affected about 68 percent of the\npopulation in Kitgum. He added that the district needed more support\nfrom the government and health agencies in eradicating it. 'The main\nrisk factor is the low latrine coverage in the newly-created IDP\n[internally displaced persons] camps or in the villages to which the\npeople are returning. Most people use the bush and when it rains, the\nwater takes the faeces into water sources and contaminates them,' he explained.\n\nThere is also the problem of inadequate safe drinking water sources\nin the villages, he said, and called for the drilling of more\nboreholes. 'Our population still practices communal hand washing, or\nuse water in the same basin. So if one of them visited the toilet and\nhis or her faeces had hepatitis E [virus], then the others will\ndefinitely get the infection.'\n\nMeanwhile, [reporter] Mary Karugaba [notes] that the Acholi\nParliamentary Group has expressed concern about the rate at which the\ndisease is spreading. They said it has spread to the districts of\nPader, Gulu, and Amuru, covering the entire Acholi region. Addressing\njournalists on Thursday [31 Jul 2008], the group, led by chairperson\nLivingstone Okello Okello, said: 'An average of 112 people share one\nlatrine in the IDP camps, almost 6 times above the standard\nrequirement of 20 people per latrine.' They also said there was need\nfor water vessels of 20 litre capacity with narrow necks to replace\nthe wide neck pots that are highly responsible for household water\ncontamination. The health ministry has urged people in affected areas\nto boil all drinking water and keep water containers clean.\n\n[Byline: Justin Moro]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The hepatitis E outbreak in the Kitgum region of northern Uganda,\nwhich began in October 2007, has not yet been contained and indeed is\nworsening. The team\nwill assess the extent of the epidemic, the level of intervention\nagainst the disease and identify response gaps, Kitgum District\nChairman Komakech John Ogwok told IRIN.\n\n'The biggest challenge we have is the attitude of the population,' he\nsaid, explaining that many people preferred to visit traditional\nhealers first and only go to health centres as a last resort. No\ntreatment is available for patients who have reached an acute stage\nof infection, 'but HEV infections are usually self-limited and\nhospitalisation is generally not required', according to the World\nHealth Organization. 'Unless people change their attitude, it will be\ndifficult to get rid of the disease and more people will continue\ndying,' said Ogwok.\n\nCommunity mobilisers in affected areas said sanitation and hygiene\nconditions were very poor in IDP camps and the villages to which\npeople were returning in the wake of a rebel insurgency in the north.\n\nHepatitis E is a viral disease spread via the faecal-oral route.\nOutbreaks tend to be linked to contaminated water or food supplies.\nMortality rates are generally low, ranging from 0.5 to 4.0 percent.\nBut among pregnant women in their 3rd trimester this rate can rise to\n20 percent.\n\n'The number of hepatitis E cases is continuing to increase in the\ndistrict... Over 3082 cases have been registered in the district\nsince October 2007, with 64 deaths,' Kitgum District Health Officer\nAlex Olwedo told IRIN. 'The majority of those getting the infection\nand dying are women who are pregnant and it's really disturbing,' he said.\n\nA report by the Kitgum health directorate said the worst affected\nareas of the district were Madi Opei sub-county, which is the\nepicentre of the disease with 1114 cases, followed by Agoro with 685\ncases, Paloga with 607 cases, Padibe 304 cases, Mucwini 277 cases and\nLokung with 25 cases. Others are Layamo with 16, Orom 12 cases,\nKitgum town with 12 cases, Akwnag with 3 and Palabek Gem with 2 cases.\n\nAt Padibe health centre, an 82-year-old, had recently been diagnosed\nwith the viral disease. 'He is the 4th person to suffer from\nhepatitis E in our family. Two of his sons and his elder brother died\nof hepatitis E last month,' said the patient's son. Gustave Opoka,\nthe doctor in charge of Padibe emergency health unit, said 60 cases\nwere reported there within a period of 3 weeks. A near-term pregnant\nwoman who had been brought to the health centre critically ill had\nrecently succumbed to the disease, said Opoka.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The hepatitis E outbreak in the Kitgum region of northern Uganda\nwhich began in October 2007 has not yet been contained. It spread to Agoro, Mucwini, Paloga,\nPotika, Padibe, and Lukung sub-counties and is now threatening Kitgum\ntown council,' the deputy resident district commissioner, Sylvester\nOpira, said on Tuesday [27 May 2008]. 'We are urging people to visit\nhealth centres if they feel feverish. Health minister\nStephen Mallinga told journalists that hepatitis E, which was reported in\nthe 4 parishes of Madi, Opei Sub-county in Kitgum late last year [2007],\nhas now spread to Yumbe District in West Nile and 4 other sub-counties in\nKitgum District.\n\nDr Mallinga was on Friday [9 May 2008] giving an update of the action taken\nby the Ministry of Health to control hepatitis E. 'During the last 2\nmonths, Adravu Sub-county in Yumbe District has also reported cases among\nthe Sudanese refugees, but fortunately, no more cases have been reported in\nthe district,' Dr Mallinga said.\n\nYumbe District health officer Alfred Yayi told Daily Monitor on Friday [10\nMay 2008] that so far 23 cases have been reported in Yumbe out of which 4\ndied. Dr Yayi said all the cases were from a refugee camp where about 10\n000 refugees from South Sudan are living. He said the United Nations high\ncommissioner for refugees in collaboration with the International Committee\nof the Red Cross have started repatriating the refugees. Dr Yayi said so\nfar about 3000 refugees have been repatriated and that the district, the\nMinistry of Health, and other partners are sensitising the residents on\ngood sanitation practices to contain the disease.\n\nSince last October [2007], a viral disease that WHO says has no cure, has\nbeen killing people in near the frontier with Sudan. Dr Mallinga said the\nnumber of hepatitis E cases has increased from 1109 last month [April 2008]\nto 1262 and that 25 people have died. About 81 per cent of the deaths have\noccurred among pregnant women. Pregnant women are at a higher risk of dying\nthan other people because during pregnancy, the blood volume in the body\nincreases by over 40 per cent and weakens the immune system, which makes\nmothers susceptible to any illnesses including minor diseases.\n\nDr Mallinga said the weekly trends indicate that the number of cases\ncontinues to go up due to increased contamination of water during the rainy\nseason. He said during the past week, 156 new cases have been reported, and\none person died.\n\nHepatitis E is a viral disease transmitted through eating or drinking water\nor food contaminated with faeces. Some of its symptoms include fever, dark\nyellow urine, and yellow eyes. The transmission is similar to that of other\ndiarrhoeal diseases such as cholera and dysentery. It is very common in\nareas with low latrine coverage, inadequate safe water, and poor personal\nhygiene. Dr Mallinga said water testing in the affected areas has revealed\nthat 32 per cent of wells are contaminated with human waste. At the\nhousehold level, 75 per cent of the household clay pots used to store and\ncollect water are contaminated. He said communities are being mobilised\nthrough public education meetings, home visits, and radio talk shows among\nothers. More pit latrines and safe water sources have been constructed so\nthat people can stop using contaminated water.\n\nDr Mallinga also said the Health Ministry has remitted an additional\nfunding of UGX 25 million (about USD 15 000) to Kitgum to help the district\ncope with the limited number of staff in health facilities. The Ministry is\nproviding families with jerricans, which cannot easily be contaminated.\nInvestigations done by the Ministry of Health have revealed that\ncommunities using pots to store drinking water are at a higher risk of\ngetting infection.\n\n[byline: Jane Nafula]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Hepatitis E is a liver disease caused by hepatitis E virus (HEV), which is\ntransmitted in much the same way as other enteric viruses. Hepatitis E\noutbreaks have occurred worldwide in recent years. The signs and symptoms\nof HEV infection are loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, discoloured urine,\njaundice, and abdominal pain. There is, however, no chronic (long term)\ninfection. Hepatitis E is more severe among pregnant women, especially in\nthe 3rd trimester. Transmission from person to person may occur.\n\nIt seems likely in view of the deficiencies in basic sanitation pertaining\nin rural Uganda that other enteric agents in addition to HEV are\ncontributing to the epidemic situation described above.\n\nA map of Uganda showing the location of Kitgum and Yumbo in the north and\nnorth west of the country respectively can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/uganda_pol_2005.jpg>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 12 May 2008\n During the last 2\nmonths, Adravu Sub-county in Yumbe District has also reported cases among\nthe Sudanese refugees, but fortunately, no more cases have been reported in\nthe district,' Dr Mallinga said.
