The appeal was made\nin view of the higher incidence of viral hepatitis E infection\nrecently.\n\nThe Consultant, Community Medicine, of CHP, Dr S K Chuang, said a\ntotal of 45 cases had been reported to CHP so far this year [2008],\nwhile the figure for the same period in 2007 was 25. The figures for\nthe whole year of 2005, 2006, and 2007 were 33, 34, and 64\nrespectively.\n\nThe cases were distributed throughout Hong Kong and involved patients\naged between 16 and 84. So far, the food histories provided by the\npatients have not shown a single common source outbreak related to\nany particular food premises, Dr Chuang said.\n\nDr Chuang said hepatitis E was acquired by ingestion of contaminated\nfood or water and therefore it is preventable by observing good\npersonal and food hygiene. The incubation period ranges from 15 to 64\ndays before onset of symptoms. Hepatitis E is usually more active\nduring the winter and spring seasons.\n\n'Clinical features of acute hepatitis E resemble those of other types\nof viral hepatitis, including anorexia, malaise, fever, and vomiting,\nfollowed by jaundice, passing tea-coloured urine, and hepatomegaly.\nMost of the patients recover in 3 to 6 weeks. However, pregnant\npatients carry a higher risk of severe disease from the infection,'\nDr Chuang said.\n\nTo prevent hepatitis E infection, the public is advised to take the\nfollowing precautions:\n- most important, cook food thoroughly before consumption;\n- avoid raw food or semi-cooked food;\n- purchase fresh food from reliable sources and do not patronise\nillegal hawkers;\n- handle and store raw and cooked food, especially seafood,\nseparately (upper compartment of the refrigerator for cooked food and\nlower compartment for raw food) to avoid cross contamination;\n- store perishable food in the refrigerator, well covered, and keep\nthe temperature of the refrigerator at or below 4 deg C (39 deg F);\n- wash hands properly with soap and water before eating or handling\nfood, and after going to the toilet.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[A recent paper in the April 2008 issue of the Journal of Medical\nVirology (2008; 80(4): 646-58) should be consulted for an up-to-date\naccount of hepatitis E disease.\n\nFrom the Abstract: 'Hepatitis E virus (HEV), the sole member of the\ngenus _Hepevirus_ in the family _Hepeviridae_, has been the major\ncause of several outbreaks of waterborne hepatitis in tropical and\nsubtropical countries and of sporadic cases of viral hepatitis in\nendemic and industrialized countries. Transmission of HEV occurs\npredominantly by the fecal-oral route although parenteral and\nperinatal routes have been implicated. The overall death rate among\nyoung adults and pregnant women is 0.5-3 per cent and 15-20 per cent,\nrespectively.\n\nThere are 4 major genotypes of HEV and a single serotype. At present,\nthere are approximately 1600 sequences of HEV that are already\navailable at INSDC (International Nucleotide Sequence Database\nCollaboration) of both human and animal isolates. Diagnostic and\nmolecular assays have been described for the accurate differentiation\nof ongoing from remote infection of HEV.\n\nIdentification and characterization of swine HEV in China, Japan, the\nUnited States, and many other countries and their close relationship\nto locally characterized human HEV found in the same geographic areas\nprove that HEV is indeed a zoonotic virus and that domestic swine,\nwild deer, and boars are reservoirs of HEV in nature. A cell culture\nsystem for the propagation of the virus has been described, and a\nvery successful phase 2 vaccine trial has been completed.' - Mod.CP]", "summary": "\n\nTo prevent hepatitis E infection, the public is advised to take the\nfollowing precautions:\n- most important, cook food thoroughly before consumption;\n- avoid raw food or semi-cooked food;\n- purchase fresh food from reliable sources and do not patronise\nillegal hawkers;\n- handle and store raw and cooked food, especially seafood,\nseparately (upper compartment of the refrigerator for cooked food and\nlower compartment for raw food) to avoid cross contamination;\n- store perishable food in the refrigerator, well covered, and keep\nthe temperature of the refrigerator at or below 4 deg C (39 deg F);\n- wash hands properly with soap and water before eating or handling\nfood, and after going to the toilet. A total of 314 cases\nwith 11 deaths have been registered since the epidemic began to\nspread in November 2007 and the outbreak in Madi Opei has shown\nminimal reduction in its trend of progression. About 75 percent of\nthe cases are between the age group of 15 and 44 years. Meanwhile,\nabout 60 percent (186/314) of the cases are females. The risk factors\nresponsible for this continued transmission of HEV have been\ndiscovered to be extremely low latrine coverage, contamination of\nwater at household levels and poor hygiene practices in the affected\nIDP camps.\n\nAccording to findings of a situational analysis carried out in 25\nvillages located in Madi Opei, an average of 112 people share one\nlatrine facility within the IDP camp. This is almost 6 times above\nthe standard requirement of 20 people per latrine facility.\nFurthermore, most villages are lacking latrines and thus the\ncommunities have formed the habits of open defecation. Most of the\navailable latrines are not being maintained, making their use\ndifficult. This also encourages open air defecation.\n\nHygiene practices at household levels such as routine washing hands\nwith soap after visiting the toilet or before meals are hardly\npracticed. Despite the fact that soaps were distributed to the\ncommunity, there are no indications to show that soap was being used\nfor hand washing at all. Water samples (from pots and buckets)\ncollected from households showed heavy presence of coli\nmicro-organisms giving the indication that contamination of water is\ntaking place at household levels, attributed to the use of pots and\npoor personal hygiene practices.\n\nMadi Opei IDP camp has a total of 19 functional boreholes that supply\noptimal amount of water to the community. Bucket chlorination is\nbeing conducted at all water sources in Madi Opei and the\nsurrounding. It was established that there were occasional\ninterruption in the supply of chlorine tablets, resulting into\nerratic discontinuation in chlorination of water at source. This was\nlargely attributed to weak supervisory/oversight role provided to the\nchlorination activity.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Hepatitis E is a liver disease caused by hepatitis E virus (HEV)\nwhich is transmitted in much the same way as other enteric viruses.\nHepatitis E outbreaks have occurred world-wide in recent years (see\nreferences below). 'The disease\nhas a high mortality rate among pregnant women and females suffering from\nhepatitis E should be immediately rushed to SKIMS or SMHS hospital for\ntreatment,' a specialist said adding any delay could prove fatal for both\nmother and child.\nThe disease, the health expert said, damages the liver immensely. 'Due to\nthe disease the functioning of liver gets hampered as bilrubin metabolism\nis hindered,' the expert said. The expert cautioned the people especially\nthe pregnant women living in the affected area not to drink the tap water.\n'The chlorination of water in the treatment plant doesn't kill the\nhepatitis E virus but is effective for other type of pathogens,' the expert\nsaid adding the people should continuously boil water for 20 minutes to\nkill the virus. The expert said Srinagar Municipal Corporation should gear\nup and launch a continuous and sustained cleanliness drive in the area.\n'The SMC should ensure proper disposal of waste in the affected areas,' the\nexpert further said.\nGiving details about the virus and the type of disease, renowned\ngastroenterologist Professor Muhammad Subhan Khuroo said, 'Hepatitis E is\nan enterically transmitted, self limiting, acute viral hepatitis caused by\nwell characterized RNA virus, the hepatitis E virus. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis a", "hepatitis c", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "28103", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hepatitis E virus - Europe (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=28103", "date": "2007-09-20 03:00:08", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E VIRUS - EUROPE (02)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 18 Sep 2007\nFrom: Benjamin Cowie <Benjamin.Cowie@mh.org.au>\n\nre: ProMED-mail post 'Hepatitis E virus - Europe 20070918.3093'\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Moderator's referred question from Dr Robert McNair Scott is an\ninteresting one, which has been the subject of previous research. The near\nuniversal prevalence of antibodies to hepatitis A virus (HAV) by the age of\n5-10 in endemic areas (1) argues strongly against HAV as the cause of large\nepidemics of hepatitis amongst adults in these regions.\nIn 1980, it was shown that HAV was not the cause of a large outbreak of\nwater-born hepatitis in Kashmir (2,3) resulting in 52 000 hepatitis cases\nand 1560 deaths.\nIn 1993, Arankalle and colleagues (4) reported the results of a\nretrospective seroepidemiologic study of 17 epidemics of water-born\nhepatitis, none of which were caused by HAV.\nIn 16 (94 per cent) of these epidemics, evidence of recent hepatitis E\nvirus (HEV) infection was found in 60-100 per cent of patients studied,\nincluding in the large epidemic in Delhi in 1955 involving 29 000 patients\nwith hepatitis, in which all of the 28 archived serum samples were positive\nfor anti-HEV IgM.\nThus, it is indeed likely that many outbreaks of epidemic hepatitis\npreviously ascribed to HAV were in fact caused by HEV (1). With respect to\nthe post preceding Dr McNair Scott's question, we have previously looked at\nHEV infection in Victoria, Australia (5,6). Although autochthonous HEV\ninfection is increasingly recognised in 'non-endemic' countries, most\ninfections are imported, although referral bias is likely to apply\n(clinicians are less likely to refer for HEV testing in the absence of a\ntravel history).\nI would support the call for increased testing to better explore the\nepidemiology of HEV in non-endemic areas, not least because trends in such\ndiagnoses may even provide early warning of evolving epidemics in endemic,\nless resource-rich areas with less access to routine testing.\nWe have previously compared trends in our laboratory diagnoses of HEV\nagainst reports of HEV outbreaks on ProMED-mail, with a notable association\nbetween reports of epidemics in India and significant increases in\nhighly-reactive anti-HEV serology results at our laboratory (6). A similar\nassociation was not observed for epidemics in other countries, reflecting\nthe close ties and relative frequency of travel between India and Australia.\nReferences\n----------\n1. Emerson SU, Purcell RH. Running like water--the omnipresence of\nhepatitis E. N Engl J Med 2004; 351(23): 2367-8.\n2. Wong DC, Purcell RH, Sreenivasan MA, Prasad SR, Pavri KM. Epidemic and\nendemic hepatitis in India: evidence for a non-A, non-B hepatitis virus\naetiology. Lancet 1980; 2: 876-9.\n3. Khuroo MS. Study of an epidemic of non-A, non-B hepatitis. Possibility\nof another human hepatitis virus distinct from post-transfusion non-A,\nnon-B type. Am J Med 1980; 68(6): 818-24.\n4. Arankalle VA, Chadha MS, Tsarev SA, Emerson SU, Risbud AR, Banerjee K,\net al. Seroepidemiology of water-borne hepatitis in India and evidence for\na third enterically-transmitted hepatitis agent. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA\n1994; 91(8): 3428-32.\n5. Cowie BC, Adamopoulos J, Carter K, Kelly H. Hepatitis E infections,\nVictoria, Australia. Emerg Infect Dis 2005; 11(3): 482-4.\n6. Cowie BC, Breschkin A, Kelly H. Hepatitis E virus: overseas epidemics\nand Victorian travellers. The following summary was\nabstracted from the Gideon database (<http://www.GideonOnline.com>).\n\nBotswana:\n---------\n1985 - An outbreak (245 cases) in Maun was ascribed to possible water\ncontamination.\n\nCentral African Republic:\n-------------------------\n2002 - An outbreak (48 confirmed cases) in Bangui may have been\ncaused by contaminated drinking water.\n2004 - An outbreak (10 cases) in Bangui was caused by contaminated\nwater sold by a street vendor.\n\nChad:\n-----\n2004 - An outbreak (1442 cases, 46 fatal) was reported in Goz Amer\nand Goz Beida - Sudanese refugee camps.\n2005 - An outbreak (50 or more fatal cases) was reported in the area\nof Goz Beida (eastern Chad).\n\nDemocratic Republic of Congo:\n-----------------------------\n2006 - An outbreak (341 cases, 13 fatal) was reported in Equateur Province.\n\nDjibouti:\n---------:\n1993 - An outbreak of mixed hepatitis A and hepatitis E infection in\nDjibouti City was caused by contaminated water.\n\nEthiopia:\n---------\n1988 to 1989 - An outbreak (423 hospitalized) of acute hepatitis E\nwas reported among military personnel in the north.\n\nIvory Coast:\n------------\n1986 - An outbreak was reported in Tortiya (northwestern region), the\n1st well-documented outbreak of hepatitis E in Africa.\n\nNamibia:\n--------\n1983 - An outbreak (201 known cases, 7 fatal - 6 of these pregnant)\nwas reported in the Kavango region.\n1995 - An outbreak of presumed water-borne hepatitis E was reported\n(no details given).\n\nSomalia:\n--------\n1985 to 1986 - Outbreaks (2000 cases or more, 87 fatal) were reported\nin 4 refugee camps. 40 (46 percent) of the persons who died were\npregnant women.\n1988 to 1989 - An outbreak (11 413 cases, 346 fatal) was reported in\nthe Shebeli River in the Lower Shebeli region.\n\nSudan:\n------\n1985 - An outbreak (63 fatal, including 11 pregnant women) was\nreported among refugees.\n2004 - An outbreak (6 861 cases, 87 fatal) was reported among\nrefugees in the Darfur region. Now Europeans are also contracting the disease here,\nsay scientists today [Mon 3 Sep 2007] at the Society for General\nMicrobiology's 161st meeting at the University of Edinburgh, UK.\nHepatitis E virus is one of the few viruses which has been shown to be\ntransmitted directly from animals through food. It was recently thought to\nbe confined to developing countries, and although scientists are still\nunsure exactly how it spreads to people, direct contact with pigs or eating\ncontaminated pork products is a likely route.\n'If this proves to be a relevant route for pig to human infection for\nhepatitis E in Europe, food safety regulations might need to be adapted\naccordingly,' says Dutch researcher Erwin Duizer. 'Where we do find\nhepatitis E virus identified in Europe, then the strain is usually closely\nrelated to the viruses found in pigs in the same country.'\nFar fewer cases of hepatitis E virus are reported than actually occur,\nsince doctors currently rarely ask for the relevant diagnostic tests in\nmany industrialized countries. Although they do not yet know the exact\nroute for most infections, the scientists do know that these viruses can\ninfect people if they eat infected pig's livers without cooking them.\nGenetic material from hepatitis E viruses has already been detected in pig\nlivers being offered for sale in Japan, USA and the Netherlands, proving\nthat European pigs are in contact with hepatitis E. Wild boar products\ncould present a similar risk.\n'To improve understanding of this disease, doctors should routinely start\nasking for hepatitis E screening tests, even if the patient has not been\ntravelling in India, China or other countries where they might expect to be\nat risk of infection,' says Erwin Duizer. 'Once more people are correctly\ndiagnosed with viral hepatitis E, they can be treated more effectively, and\nwe can learn more on the transmission routes. Current rates of diagnosis\nare up to 13 per cent of acute viral hepatitis patients in European\ncountries, but we think the true rate is much higher. Up to 3 per cent of\nblood donors in Europe show evidence of exposure to the virus through\ndetectable antibodies. We also need to quickly work out the local route of\ninfection in Europeans, as [in] knowing if hepatitis E is directly caused\nby eating pork meat or liver or caused by foods or people being in contact\nwith pig faeces, [which] will make it possible to implement effective\npreventive measures,' says Erwin Duizer.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promedmail@promedmail.org>\n[Some time ago, Dr Robert McNair Scott <scottrmcn@cs.net> wrote to\nProMED-mail asking a question, which this Moderator failed to answer for\nwant of appropriate information. His comments have some relevance to the\nabove report, and I reproduce them below on account of their general interest.\nDr McNair Scott wrote: 'I have noted over the past several years large\noutbreaks of reportedly HAV [hepatitis A virus] being reported from central\nAsia and other developing nations with dubious able sanitary infrastructure.\n'In my experience in Nepal, the vast majority of people, 95 per cent plus,\nhave had hepatitis A by the time they reach 5 years. I believe that the\nsituation in countries like Nepal are the same. In most, if not all, of\nthese reports, the diagnosis is given without any laboratory findings to\nback it up. Are these seat of the pants diagnoses? Again, in my experience,\nlarge outbreaks of viral hepatitis in developing countries, are usually\nhepatitis E.\n'This becomes important, as the HEV vaccine that we tested in Nepal proved\nto be very effective in preventing clinical hepatitis, but the world\nproblem with this disease continues to be underestimated because of lack of\ndiagnostic tools and seat of the pants diagnoses. Even in countries like\nBritain, whose sanitary infrastructure should be good, there are those who\nare now saying that HEV is the most common cause of viral hepatitis in that\ncountry. My question is: 'Could some/all of these HAV outbreaks be in\nreality HEV?'\nDr McNair Scott's remarks have some relevance to the preceding post. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n We also need to quickly work out the local route of\ninfection in Europeans, as [in] knowing if hepatitis E is directly caused\nby eating pork meat or liver or caused by foods or people being in contact\nwith pig faeces, [which] will make it possible to implement effective\npreventive measures,' says Erwin Duizer. Wild boar products\ncould present a similar risk. To improve understanding of this disease, doctors should routinely start\nasking for hepatitis E screening tests, even if the patient has not been\ntravelling in India, China or other countries where they might expect to be\nat risk of infection,' says Erwin Duizer. ' It was recently thought to\nbe confined to developing countries, and although scientists are still\nunsure exactly how it spreads to people, direct contact with pigs or eating\ncontaminated pork products is a likely route. This becomes important, as the HEV vaccine that we tested in Nepal proved\nto be very effective in preventing clinical hepatitis, but the world\nproblem with this disease continues to be underestimated because of lack of\ndiagnostic tools and seat of the pants diagnoses. If this proves to be a relevant route for pig to human infection for\nhepatitis E in Europe, food safety regulations might need to be adapted\naccordingly,' says Dutch researcher Erwin Duizer. ' Current rates of diagnosis\nare up to 13 per cent of acute viral hepatitis patients in European\ncountries, but we think the true rate is much higher. Where we do find\nhepatitis E virus identified in Europe, then the strain is usually closely\nrelated to the viruses found in pigs in the same country.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hepatitis a", "hepatitis e"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "70523", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hepatitis E, world cruise - UK", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=70523", "date": "2008-04-05 21:00:19", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E, WORLD CRUISE - UK\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 4 Apr 2008\nSource: HPA, Health Protection Report 2008; 2(14): 4 Apr [edited]\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/news/default.htm#hepE>\n\n\nHepatitis E in passengers on a cruise ship\n------------------------------------------\nFour cases of hepatitis E infection were reported among elderly male\npassengers on a round-the-world cruise between 7 Jan 2008 and 28 Mar 2008.\nThe dates of onset were between 12 and 23 March and it is thought highly\nlikely that exposure occurred at some point during the cruise. There were a\nnumber of ports of call including: Madeira, Barbados, Acapulco, San\nFrancisco, Pago Pago (American Samoa), Nuku'Alofa (Tonga), Auckland, Sydney\nand Hong Kong.\n\nThe passenger capacity of the cruise ship is 1800 with 900 staff but, as\npeople joined and left the cruise at different points during the journey,\nthe cumulative number of passengers on board at some point during the\ncruise was 3000. Passengers were mainly from the UK but also included\nnationals from the USA, Australia, South Africa, Denmark, and Ireland.\n\nThe Health Protection Agency (HPA) has been working closely with the cruise\nship operator and port health authority to assist with investigations and\nensure all passengers receive appropriate information. The cruise company\nhas sent letters and a factsheet on hepatitis E to all passengers to inform\nthem and to advise that they seek medical advice should they develop\nsymptoms compatible with hepatitis E. They are also being asked to contact\nthe HPA directly so that linked cases might be identified.\n\nHepatitis E is a viral infection that usually produces mild disease with\nsymptoms of jaundice, dark urine and pale stools with or without nausea,\nloss of appetite and/or abdominal pain [1]. In rare cases it can prove\nfatal, particularly in pregnant women. Hepatitis E is endemic in many\ncountries in Asia, Africa and Central America. It is a relatively uncommon\ncause of hepatitis in the United Kingdom; 292 cases were reported in 2006\nand most of these were associated with travel.\n\nDirect person-to-person spread of hepatitis E is uncommon. Exposure usually\narises from contaminated food or water and can be prevented through good\nhygiene, for example:\n- drinking bottled water only if it is from a known safe supply and the\nbottle is unopened.\n- not using ice or eating anything with ice, unless the ice is made from\nsafe bottled water.\n- not eating uncooked fruits or vegetables unless peeled and washed in safe\nwater.\n- not eating foods or beverages from street vendors.\n\nThe HPA asks health professionals to ensure that any patients with symptoms\ncompatible with hepatitis E are tested. Samples (10ml EDTA whole blood)\nshould be sent to the Virus Reference Department (VRD), HPA Centre for\nInfections, 61 Colindale Avenue, London, NW9, 5HT [2]. Enquiries should be\ndirected to email address: <zoonoses@hpa.org.uk>\n\nReferences\n----------\n1.\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/webw/HPAweb&Page&HPAwebAutoListName/Page/1191942127585?p=1191942127585>\n2. Further advice on testing can be sought from VRD's Blood Borne Viruses\nUnit. Tel: 020 8327 6204,\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/webw/HPAweb&Page&HPAwebAutoListName/Page/1200660013228?p=1200660013228>\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following abstract from a publication by IK Mushahwar in the current\n(April 2008) issue of the Journal of Medical Virology [2008; 80(4): 646-58]\nprovides a useful account of hepatitis E virus and its epidemiology:\n\n'Hepatitis E virus (HEV), the sole member of the genus _Hepevirus_ in the\nfamily _Hepeviridae_, is the major cause of several outbreaks of waterborne\nhepatitis in tropical and subtropical countries and of sporadic cases of\nviral hepatitis in endemic and industrialized countries. Transmission of\nHEV occurs predominantly by the fecal-oral route although parenteral and\nperinatal routes have been implicated. The overall death rate among young\nadults and pregnant women is 0.5-3 per cent and 15-20 per cent, respectively.\n\n'HEV is a small non-enveloped particle that consists of a polyadenylated\nsingle-strand RNA molecule containing 3 discontinuous and partially\noverlapping open reading frames. There are 4 major genotypes of HEV and a\nsingle serotype. At present, there are approximately 1600 sequences of HEV\nthat are already available at INSDC of both human and animal isolates.\nDiagnostic and molecular assays have been described for the accurate\ndifferentiation of ongoing from remote infection of HEV.\n\n'Identification and characterization of swine HEV in the United States,\nJapan, and many other countries and their close relationship to locally\ncharacterized human HEV found in the same geographic areas prove that HEV\nis indeed a zoonotic virus and that domestic swine, wild deer, and boars\nare reservoirs of HEV in nature. A cell culture system for the propagation\nof the virus has been described, and a very successful phase 2 vaccine\ntrial has been completed.' - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Tel: 020 8327 6204,\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/webw/HPAweb&Page&HPAwebAutoListName/Page/1200660013228?p=1200660013228>\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following abstract from a publication by IK Mushahwar in the current\n(April 2008) issue of the Journal of Medical Virology [2008; 80(4): 646-58]\nprovides a useful account of hepatitis E virus and its epidemiology:\n\n'Hepatitis E virus (HEV), the sole member of the genus _Hepevirus_ in the\nfamily _Hepeviridae_, is the major cause of several outbreaks of waterborne\nhepatitis in tropical and subtropical countries and of sporadic cases of\nviral hepatitis in endemic and industrialized countries. Age-specific infection rates for persons ages 12 to 19\nyears are estimated at 9900 per 100 000 during periods of sporadic\ntransmission.\n433 Nepalese citizens were hospitalized (11 fatal, including one\npregnant woman) for the disease in the Kathmandu Valley during 1995;\n1166 (27 fatal, 13 antenatal women) in 1996.\nSeroprevalence surveys\n----------------------\n- 10 percent to 12 percent of the general population (1992 to 1993)\n- 16 percent to 31 percent of healthy adolescents and young adults in\nKathmandu (1996)\n- 30 percent to 37 percent of adults (1995)\n- 95 percent of adults with hepatitis (1987 to 1988)\n- 37 percent of United Nations peacekeepers in Nepal.\nSerum antibody has been demonstrated in free-roaming swine (_Sus\nscrofa domestica_), rats (_Rattus rattus brunneusculus_), bandicoots\n(_Bandicota bengalensis_) and house shrews (_Suncus murinus_) in the\nKathmandu Valley (1995).\nNotable outbreaks\n-----------------\n1973 to 1974 - An outbreak (10 000 cases) of presumed hepatitis E\ninfection was reported in Kathmandu.\n1981 to 1982 - An outbreak (4337 cases) was reported in the Kathmandu Valley.\n1995 - An outbreak (30 cases) was reported at a military training\ncamp east of Kathmandu.\nThe ProMED-mail post mentions that the current outbreak included\nNepal's Prime Minister. Blaine Hollinger\n---------------------------------------\nThe Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is classified in the family _Hepevridae_,\ngenus _Hepevirus_ (see\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Taxonomy/Browser/wwwtax.cgi>). There are\npresumed to be 5 genotypes: 1 and 2 are from humans, 3 and 4 from\nhumans and swine, and a 5th genotype is an avian HEV found in\nchickens that represents a branch distinct from human and swine HEVs.\nGenotypes 1 and 2 occur in younger populations, whereas genotypes 3\nand 4 occur in an older age group that may be immunocompromised\n(e.g., infected with HIV) and may be acquired from an animal\nreservoir. Human cases have been linked to transmission from uncooked\nmeat from wild boar and deer\nAccording to Shrestha and Scott et al: [Safety and efficacy of a\nHepatitis E virus vaccine conducted in Nepal];\n<http://www.asc2006.com/posters/KP-20.pdf> (personal communication,\n2006), there have been continuing outbreaks of hepatitis in Nepal\nresulting in increased admissions to Valley hospitals due to\njaundice, almost every year beginning in May and usually ending in\nJanuary, with lower levels of endemicity occurring throughout the\nrest of the year. Most of these cases have been identified in Valley\nhospitals around Kathmandu: Ayurvedic centers, Teku, the Tribhuvan\nUniversity Teaching Hospital, among the police and in the army.\nMajor recent outbreaks of jaundice occurred in 1996 and 1997 (170-190\ncases of jaundice reported), but from 50-120 cases of jaundice have\nbeen treated at these centers, each year, from at least 1994-2003.\nHepatitis E is assumed to be responsible for up to 75 percent of\nthese cases. A very safe and successful HEV vaccine trial was\nconcluded in 2004, in Kathmandu, by GlaxoSmithKline Biologicals, the\nArmy Institute of Research, the Nepalese Army, and the Military\nInfectious Diseases Research Program (Fort Detrick, MD) that\ndemonstrated 96 percent vaccine efficacy against the acquisition of\nHEV (95 percent CI [confidence interval] of 86-99 percent) among\napproximately 900 vaccinated individuals, when compared to a similar\nnumber of unvaccinated controls.\n--\nF. Blaine Hollinger, M.D.\nProfessor of Medicine, Virology & Epidemiology\nDirector, Eugene B. It is even\nfeared the virus cannot be eradicated.\nThe veterinary faculty at Barcelona's university recently studied to\nwhat extent pigs in Spain are infected with the hepatitis E virus.\nThis virus is capable of transferring from pigs to humans and causing\nsevere liver infections.\nThe researchers studied a total of 41 Spanish pig-production sites\nand used the ELISA test to trace hepatitis E. At 40 sites they found\nthe animals were carrying antibodies against the virus, meaning that\nthe virus was present or had been present at 97.6 percent of the\nsites.\nEspecially the older sows appeared to be carrying the virus -- 60.8\npercent of the animals proved to be doing so. In young piglets, up to\n6-weeks old, 36.2 percent proved to be infected. In older piglets,\nthe infection ratio was even higher. The outcome of the research is\nsoon to be published.\nThe researchers now say that hepatitis E has most probably become\nendemic in the Spanish pig industry.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Background information has been provided in a commentary by Mod. CP,\n(included in ProMED-mail's posting Hepatitis E - Chad (Eastern)\n20050822.2477):\n'Hepatitis E is an important public health concern in many developing\ncountries. Hepatitis E is caused by a small, single-stranded RNA\ncalicivirus-like enteric virus, now classified as the separate genus\n_Hepevivirus_. The hepatitis E virus is transmitted by the fecal-oral\nroute and is associated with fecal contamination of water supplies.\nThe hepatitis E mortality rate can reach 25 percent in pregnant women\nin deprived communities, but is generally much lower. Although\nhepatitis E disease only occurs rarely in countries with good\nhealth-care systems, the seroprevalence rate in healthy individuals\ncan be high.\nHepatitis E disease can be controlled to a large extent by provision\nof clean water and adequate sewage treatment facilities. However,\nthere is increasing evidence that hepatitis E virus is also a\nzoonotic agent and that animal reservoirs may exist. Many species of\ndomestic and wild animals have anti-hepatitis E virus antibodies, and\nanimal hepatitis E viruses closely related to human hepatitis E\nviruses have been isolated. Avian hepatitis E viruses appear to be\nless closely related to human viruses.\nSwine may be an important reservoir of the virus, as pig handlers and\nveterinarians appear to be at greater risk of infection, as indicated\nby higher antibody levels. Furthermore, cases of acute hepatitis E\nhave occurred in Japan, in association with consumption of raw pig\nand wild boar meat.\nLack of an efficient cell culture system has impeded the development\nof vaccines and therapeutic agents'.\nIn an earlier posting (Hepatitis E virus, fatal - Japan (Hokkaido)\n20041128.3183), Mod. CP commented:\n'Hepatitis E virus infection appears to be common in both farmed and\nwild swine in parts of Japan; therefore, all pig meat should be\ncooked thoroughly before consumption'.\nPigs seem not to be clinically affected by the virus but suspected to\nbe its reservoir. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Many species of\ndomestic and wild animals have anti-hepatitis E virus antibodies, and\nanimal hepatitis E viruses closely related to human hepatitis E\nviruses have been isolated. At 40 sites they found\nthe animals were carrying antibodies against the virus, meaning that\nthe virus was present or had been present at 97.6 percent of the\nsites. CP commented:\n'Hepatitis E virus infection appears to be common in both farmed and\nwild swine in parts of Japan; therefore, all pig meat should be\ncooked thoroughly before consumption'. Although\nhepatitis E disease only occurs rarely in countries with good\nhealth-care systems, the seroprevalence rate in healthy individuals\ncan be high. Source: PigProgress.net [edited]\n<http://www.pigprogress.net/ts_pi/pigprogress.portal/enc/_nfpb/true/_pageLabel/tspi_page_news_content/_desktopLabel/pigprogress/index.html>\nHepatitis E common in Spanish pigs\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n \nSpanish researchers from Barcelona University say their country's pig\nindustry is broadly infected by the hepatitis [E] virus. Swine may be an important reservoir of the virus, as pig handlers and\nveterinarians appear to be at greater risk of infection, as indicated\nby higher antibody levels. The medical centre in Kerfi is the only\none in a 50-km radius.\n\nIn one village alone, scores of people have already died. Aid workers in\nthe region are trying to help, but there are problems with access. The\nvillage of Kerfi, 80 km from the Sudanese border, is very difficult to get\nto. There are few roads and during the rainy season floodwaters create huge\nseasonal rivers, called wadis. The only way to reach the village of Kerfi\nis to cross the deep, muddy ring of water. Vital medical supplies have to\nbe floated across the wadi on rafts.\n\nEven though the hepatitis outbreak is slowing down there, more than 50\npeople in this area near the town of Goz Beida have already lost their\nlives. Doctor Camilo Kuan, who has been treating hepatitis patients at the\nvillage clinic, says there still are not enough medical facilities in this\nremote corner of Chad. 'The medical centre in Kerfi is the only one for 50\nkilometres and people can't reach it,' Dr Kuan says. 'There aren't any\nboats, there aren't horses which can cross the wadis -- people have to\nswim. So if people are ill they stay at home.'\n\nHepatitis E may not be a headline-grabbing disease like Ebola or HIV/AIDS,\nbut it can still be deadly. There is no vaccine for the disease, and there\nis also no cure.\n\nSouleymane Diabate of UNICEF says that one of the most frustrating aspects\nof the disease is how simple it is to prevent - clean drinking water and\ngood hygiene practices are all that are needed. 'It's mainly due to the\nfact that most of the localities around Goz Beida don't have drinking\nwater, the sanitation is really poor and the practice of hygiene also\ndoesn't exist,' she says. 'So most of the people are going to the river to\nfetch water for consumption. So, most of the population suffer from this\ndisease.'\n\nAs [this reporter] learnt from the medical staff here [the village of Goz\nBeida], 15 other villages are also suffering from the outbreak of hepatitis\nE. The hope now is that supplies get to them before it is too late for even\nmore people.\n\n[Byline: Stephanie Hancock]\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E is an important public health concern in many developing\ncountries. Hepatitis E is caused by a small single-stranded RNA\ncalicivirus-like enteric virus now classified as the separate genus\n_Hepevivirus_. Hepatitis E virus is transmitted by the fecal-oral route and\nis associated with fecal contamination of water supplies. The hepatitis E\nmortality rate can reach 25 percent in pregnant women in deprived\ncommunities, but is generally much lower. Although hepatitis E disease only\noccurs rarely in countries with good health-care systems, the\nseroprevalence rate in healthy individuals can be high.\n\nHepatitis E disease can be controlled to a large extent by provision of\nclean water and adequate sewage treatment facilities. However, there is\nincreasing evidence that hepatitis E virus is also a zoonotic agent and\nthat animal reservoirs may exist. Many species of domestic and wild animals\nhave anti-hepatitis E virus antibodies, and animal hepatitis E viruses\nclosely related to human hepatitis E viruses have been isolated. Avian\nhepatitis E viruses appear to be less closely related to human viruses.\nSwine may be an important reservoir of the virus, as pig handlers and\nveterinarians appear to be at greater risk of infection, as indicated by\nhigher antibody levels. Furthermore, cases of acute hepatitis E have\noccurred in Japan in association with consumption of raw pig and wild boar\nmeat.\n\nLack of an efficient cell culture system has impeded the development of\nvaccines and therapeutic agents. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInternational Journal of Antimicrobial Agents\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/ijaa>\n\nDate: Mon 22 Aug 2005\n It's mainly due to the\nfact that most of the localities around Goz Beida don't have drinking\nwater, the sanitation is really poor and the practice of hygiene also\ndoesn't exist,' she says. M. Banks (1), S. Grierson\n(1), H.J. Fellows (2), W. Stableforth (2), R. Bendall (2), and H.R.\nDalton (2); at (1) VLA - Weybridge, Addlestone, New Haw, Surrey KT15\n3NB, and (2) Royal Cornwall Hospital, Truro, Cornwall TR1 3LJ.\n'Hepatitis E caused by the enterically transmitted hepatitis E virus\n(HEV) is a major public health problem in many developing regions of\nthe world. There is now a substantial body of direct and indirect\nevidence, emerging from autochthonously acquired cases of hepatitis E\nin industrialized regions, indicating that HEV can be transmitted\nzoonotically. With the exception of pigs and sika deer, there is very\nlittle evidence for zoonotic transmission from other mammals, and the\nubiquitous nature of HEV in global pig populations has contributed to\nthe evidence that pigs represent the most likely reservoir for\nzoonotic transmission.\nIn general, in the UK and in many other industrialized regions, the\nhighest sequence homologies to the autochthonously acquired human\nstrains of HEV are not seen in human strains of other countries, but\nare closest to those detected in the respective national pig herds.\nIn some cases this homology can be 100 percent at the amino acid\nlevel (Banks et al. 2004). Although many potential transmission\nroutes have been suggested, the most direct evidence for zoonotic\ntransmission involves ingestion of HEV-infected uncooked or poorly\ncooked meat (Tei et al. 2003).\nPCR [polymerase chain reaction] studies in Japan (Yazaki et al. 2003)\nand in the Netherlands (Bouwknegt et al. 2007) detected HEV in 3 of\n197 (1.5 percent) and 4 of 62 (6.5 percent) of retail pig livers\nrespectively. The demonstration that HEV may be viable in rare-cooked\npig meat (Emerson et al. 2005) adds further credence to this\npotential route of zoonotic transmission.\nAs part of an investigation into autochthonously acquired hepatitis E\nin Cornwall (England), samples of pig liver were collected from 80\nretail outlets in that county. Samples were anonymised and submitted\nto the Veterinary Laboratories Agency (VLA) in Weybridge for testing.\nA PCR using degenerate primers was used to detect HEV in the samples.\nIn contrast to the findings in Japan and the Netherlands, none of the\npig liver samples from Cornwall proved positive for HEV.\nAlthough this result cannot be used as an indicator of national\nfreedom from HEV in retail pig livers, and no attempts were made to\nsource the farm origins of the pig samples, it does indicate that in\nCornwall at least, exposure to HEV via pig liver is likely to be low.\nThis leaves the likely routes of transmission for the 21 cases of\nautochthonously acquired hepatitis E in the county [Cornwall] in\nrecent years (Dalton et al. 2007) undetermined.\nIt would be useful to conduct a nationally representative survey of\nHEV in retail pig livers in order to assess more completely this\npotential transmission route in the UK. This would enable a better\nfocus on studies of the increasing number of autochthonously acquired\ncases of hepatitis E diagnosed in southwest England and other regions\nof the UK, in almost all of which the transmission route remains\nunknown. In addition, use of in vitro cultivation methods for HEV\nwould give greater significance to the risks associated with HEV\nPCR-positive pig products.'\n[The original paper should be consulted to access the references\nembedded in the text of the Abstract. - Mod.CP]\n--\nPablo Nart\n<pablo.nart@terra.es>\n[HEV is associated in humans with outbreaks of enterically\ntransmitted acute hepatitis. HEV is similar to viruses belonging to\nthe family _Caliciviridae_ (the noroviruses and their ilk), but\nbiologically distinct. HEV is considered to be endemic as a\ndisease-producing agent in semi-tropical and tropical regions,\nwhereas antibody prevalence surveys suggest a global distribution of\nthe virus, perhaps in a less pathogenic form.\nHEV exists as a single serotype with extensive cross-reactivity among\ncirculating human and swine strains. Cross-reactive antibodies with\nepitopes of human strains have been detected in numerous rodents and\nother mammals but the putative viruses have not been isolated.\nFour distinct genotypes of HEV have been defined. The HEV strains\nidentified in swine are closely related antigenically and genetically\nto human HEV genotypes 3 and 4 strains. Interspecies transmission of\ngenotype 3 strains between swine and primates has been demonstrated\nexperimentally but evidence of natural transmission is lacking.\nThe above research paper by Banks et al. records the prevalence of\nHEV in southwest England, but leaves unresolved the question of the\nsource of the virus and its route of transmission.\nA map of the counties of England with Cornwall at the extreme\nsouthwest can be viewed at:\n<http://www.travelnotes.org/1800/UK/images/england_counties.gif>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n With the exception of pigs and sika deer, there is very\nlittle evidence for zoonotic transmission from other mammals, and the\nubiquitous nature of HEV in global pig populations has contributed to\nthe evidence that pigs represent the most likely reservoir for\nzoonotic transmission. This would enable a better\nfocus on studies of the increasing number of autochthonously acquired\ncases of hepatitis E diagnosed in southwest England and other regions\nof the UK, in almost all of which the transmission route remains\nunknown. NIV officer-in-charge\nA.C. Mishra said 5 samples had tested positive for the virus. 'Actually,\nthis is the 1st time it has taken an epidemic proportion. Normally, the\nvirus is in an endemic form with stray cases,' Mishra told Newsline. He\nconfirmed that the virus spread through contaminated water. 'This (positive\ntest for hepatitis E virus) definitely means that the water supply has been\ncontaminated due to leaks in the sewage line,' he said. Mishra said as an\nimmediate measure, the leaking drainage lines should be repaired. He said\nthey were yet to receive samples from Alandi. 'The NIV team has visited\nAlandi,' Mishra said.\nMeanwhile, the district health authorities have restricted the sale of ice.\n'Hoteliers, sugarcane, and fruit juice stall owners have been strictly\nwarned not to use ice,' Zilla Parishad CEO Rajendra Chavan said. Chavan,\nalong with district health officer B Nanavare, visited Baramati, Alandi and\nSherewadi on Monday. Nanavare said blocks of ice being used at sugarcane\njuice stalls were contaminated at Baramati and Alandi. Nanavare said a\ndoor-to-door survey was under way at Alandi. A WHO\nepidemiologist, Dr Jean Robert Likofata, said on Tuesday [17 Oct 2006] in\nthe capital, Kinshasa, that 4 health zones around the town of Gemena in\nEquateur were threatened by the disease, which has an incubation period of\nbetween 3 and 8 weeks. He said the whole province was threatened by this\nepidemic because Gemena was an 'epicentre', as it is a market town,\nfacilitating contact with almost the whole population in the area.\nMoreover, Likofata said cases of hepatitis E had been recorded up to 65 km\nsouthwest in the health zone of Bwamanda; 105 km west in the Tandaba zone\nand at least 44 km northwest in the health zones of Bogose and Nubea. 'This\ndisease is transmitted through contaminated water, especially when hygiene\nis not good when it comes to the washing of hands,' Likofata said. 'And at\nthis market, which dominates Gemena town, you have businessmen coming from\nall around the province.'\nLikofata led a medical team to Gemena when the first cases were reported in\nJuly 2006, to inspect samples that were later sent to a laboratory in\nKinshasa. Initially, Likofata said, the outbreak was suspected to be yellow\nfever until the laboratory results confirmed it was hepatitis E. He said\nthose affected initially exhibit flu-like symptoms, with high fever, nausea\nand loss of appetite, which could last a week. The next phase is yellowing\neyes, pale faeces and dark urine consistent with liver disease. There is no\neffective treatment aside from bed-rest and fluid replacement, so\nprevention is key.\nBesides sharing information about the disease's symptoms with staff in the\nmain health centres in Equateur, the medical team also conducted awareness\ncampaigns to inform the public about the importance of hygiene in the\nprevention of hepatitis E.\n--\nBrent Barrett\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n[Hepatitis E virus, has caused large epidemics of enterically transmitted\nself-limiting acute viral hepatitis throughout the Indian subcontinent,\nsoutheast and central Asia, the Middle East, parts of Africa, and Mexico.\nSeroprevalence surveys indicate that the virus is prevalent elsewhere\nsuggesting the existence of strains of differing virulence.\nHepatitis E is a cause of considerable morbidity and mortality and poses a\nmajor health problem in endemic regions. Hepatitis E epidemics are\nwaterborne outbreaks. During these outbreaks, overall attack rates range\nfrom 1 to 15 percent, being higher among adults (3 to 30 percent) than\namong children (0.2 to 10 percent). The outbreaks are characterized by a\nparticularly high attack rate and mortality among pregnant women. In\nnon-endemic regions, hepatitis E accounts for less than 1 percent of\nreported cases of acute viral hepatitis.\nThe clinical disease in humans is typical of viral hepatitis. The liver\nappears to be the only target organ of infection, and its extrahepatic\nmanifestations have been rare. The incubation period ranges from 15 to 50\ndays. The preicteric phase lasts for 1-10 (average 3-4) days, and\ngastrointestinal symptoms, such as epigastric pain, nausea and vomiting,\nare frequently reported. The icteric phase begins abruptly, with the\nappearance of jaundice, dark urine and clay-coloured stools. In\nuncomplicated cases these symptoms last 12-15 days, and complete recovery\nusually takes place within 1 month. About half the patients develop fever\nand 2/3 complain of arthralgia.\nClinical studies have shown that elevation of serum alanine\naminotransferase levels occur as a single peak preceding or coinciding with\nthe onset of jaundice, which is similar to most other forms of viral\nhepatitis. In disease-endemic regions, this infection constitutes an\nimportant cause of fulminant hepatic damage. Pregnant women, particularly\nthose in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters, are more frequently affected during\nhepatitis E outbreaks and have a worse outcome. Mortality rates among\npregnant women, especially those infected in the 3rd trimester, range\nbetween 5 and 25 percent. Frequency of abortions, stillbirths and neonatal\ndeaths is also increased among hepatitis E virus-infected pregnant women.\nControl of hepatitis E outbreaks consists predominantly of measures to\ninterrupt water-borne transmission of disease and appropriate education of\nthe population at risk.\nA map of the Democratic Republic of Congo showing the location of Gemena in\nthe north of Equateur Provincec an be accessed via\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/english/htmain.htm>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Besides sharing information about the disease's symptoms with staff in the\nmain health centres in Equateur, the medical team also conducted awareness\ncampaigns to inform the public about the importance of hygiene in the\nprevention of hepatitis E.\n-- A WHO\nepidemiologist, Dr Jean Robert Likofata, said on Tuesday [17 Oct 2006] in\nthe capital, Kinshasa, that 4 health zones around the town of Gemena in\nEquateur were threatened by the disease, which has an incubation period of\nbetween 3 and 8 weeks. West\nDarfur remains the most affected area.\nThere are ongoing control measures being implemented in the 3 states.\nHealth agencies, including the Ministry of Health, UNICEF, Oxfam, Medecins\ndu Monde-France, Medecins sans Frontieres-Holland, the United Nations Joint\nLogistics Centre (UNJLC), and the International Committee of the Red Cross\nhave been working with WHO to scale up mass hygiene education programs,\nincrease the availability of soap, dig new wells, and ensure effective\nchlorination of water bladders and wells. Based on the Food Sanitation Law, the Ministry and the Hokkaido\nPrefectural Government started examining the health of other patrons\nof the barbecue restaurant and checking its remaining stocks of meat.\nAccording to health officials, the 6 were related and went to the\nrestaurant with 7 other relatives in mid-August 2004. There, they\nreportedly ate pork liver and other organs, in addition to beef and\nchicken. Among them, a man in his 60s developed symptoms of fulminant\nhepatitis and was hospitalized in late September [2004]. Hepatitis E\nvirus was detected in his blood, and the man died several days later.\nSince recipients of the blood donated by his son were later found to\nbe infected with the virus, the Ministry and blood experts decided to\ntest the blood of the surviving 12 relatives. [Subsequently], they\ndetected hepatitis E virus [nucleic acid] in the son's blood and\nantibody against the virus -- proof of infection -- in his and 5\nother relatives' blood, said the officials.\nSince the disease has a latent period of about 6 weeks on average, it\nis normally difficult to determine which food is the source of\ncontagion. However, as a result of thorough interviews, the Ministry\nand [other specialists] found that most of the 6 people [who\ncontracted] hepatitis E ate both barbecued pork liver and organs. The\n7 others [who did not contract hepatitis E] did not eat both of them,\naccording to health officials.\nSince the meal at the barbecue restaurant was the only time the 13\nrelatives had eaten together in the relevant time frame, the Ministry\nconcluded that one of the pork dishes, most probably the liver, was\nthe source of infection. At this restaurant, patrons are [expected]\nto barbecue meat themselves, said officials of the Ministry and the\nHokkaido Prefectural Government. Many patrons are said to prefer\neating the dish rare.\nThough no other patrons have been reported to be infected yet, their\nhealth, along with that of employees at the restaurant, is being\nmonitored, and sanitation measures at the restaurant are being\nexamined. In past cases, groups of people were reportedly infected\nwith hepatitis E virus [as a result of] eating [improperly cooked]\nwild boar or deer [meat]. However, since hepatitis E virus has also\nbeen detected in ordinary pork liver at meat shops, the Ministry has\nstarted urging the public not to eat pork liver without cooking it\nthoroughly. 'It is important to realize the dangers of eating raw\nmeat of not only wild, but also domestic animals,' said a hepatitis E\nspecialist. 'Research has shown that infection is likely to take\nplace only if a food contains a large amount of hepatitis E virus.\nInfection can be prevented if the meat is heated enough.'\nIn developing countries, a major source of hepatitis E virus\ninfection is said to be drinking water. Though in developed countries\na route of infection has not been established, an increasing number\nof experts say infection is caused by eating raw or under-cooked wild\ngame.\nJaundice and other symptoms of the disease develop in 15 to 50 days\nafter infection, but most patients recover naturally without\ndeveloping chronic hepatitis. The mortality rate is said to be one\npercent, but pregnant women have a higher mortality rate, according\nto the experts.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This outbreak of hepatitis E in the Hokkaido Prefecture of Japan\nappears to have been restricted to a single family party at a\nrestaurant where customers barbecued their own meat. No other\ncustomers were affected, but some others contracted infection through\nblood donations from one member of the family party, the son of the\ndeceased (though the precise details of this are obscure). No\ninformation is provided concerning the consequences of this\nblood-borne transmission, and the matter is left hanging in the air.\nFurther information is awaited.\nUnlike previous outbreaks in Japan (see the ProMED-mail posts listed\nbelow), the hepatitis E virus-contaminated meat did not originate\nfrom wild-life but was identified as liver tissue originating from\nfarmed pigs. Hepatitis E virus infection appears to be common in both\nfarmed and wild swine in parts of Japan; therefore, all pig meat\nshould be cooked thoroughly before consumption. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "--------------------------------------------------------------------------\n6 people who ate pork liver in August [2004] at a barbecue restaurant\nin Kitami, Hokkaido, contracted hepatitis E virus infection, and one\nof them died of fulminant hepatitis, it was learned on Sat 27 Nov\n2004. The [RNA] that was detected is very similar to that\nfound in hepatitis E [virus-infected] patients who contracted the virus in\n2003 in Hyogo and Tottori prefectures, strongly suggesting that the people\ncontracted the virus from wild boar meat. Noting that heat kills the virus,\nthe ministry has urged people to cook wild boar thoroughly and avoid eating\nit raw or rare.\n2 research groups captured 85 wild boars in Nagano, Aichi, Wakayama, Hyogo\nand Nagasaki prefectures between November 2003 and April 2004. The\nresearchers detected the virus' [RNA] in the liver and blood of 8 boars; 3\neach in Hyogo and Nagasaki prefectures, and one each in Aichi and Wakayama\nprefectures. Among these, the [RNA] found in boar in Aichi, Wakayama and\nHyogo prefectures was virtually identical to that found in the patients.\nIn Nagasaki and Tottori prefectures during 2003, the virus was discovered in\na number of people, each of whom had eaten wild boar meat and liver. The\nboar meat had been strongly suspected as the cause, but until now,\nresearchers had not found any decisive evidence.\n--\nChristian Griot\n<christian.griot@vip.admin.ch>\n[Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is globally distributed and is transmitted\nenterically as well as between humans and animals. Phylogenetic analysis has\nidentified 5 distinct HEV genotypes (types III and V have been confirmed as\npresent in Japan). In developing countries HEV is transmitted principally by\nthe fecal-oral route, and water-borne epidemics are common. In\nindustrialized countries zoonotic transmission may be more usual. Sporadic\ncases of hepatitis E have been reported in Japan in the past, and widespread\ninfection of HEV has been reported among wild rats in different parts of the\ncountry. Zoonotic spread of HEV is indicated by the fact that human and\nswine isolates of HEV are quite similar in terms of nucleotide sequence, and\nexperimental cross-species transmission of swine HEV to a chimpanzee and of\nhuman HEV to swine have been demonstrated. The detection of hepatitis E\nvirus in 8 of 85 wild boar in 5 prefectures inn Japan confirms the suspicion\nthat the outbreaks of hepatitis E virus infection in Nagasaki and Tottori\nprefectures in 2003 (described in the ProMED-mail posts listed below) were\ninitiated by the consumption of improperly cooked wild boar meat. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The detection of hepatitis E\nvirus in 8 of 85 wild boar in 5 prefectures inn Japan confirms the suspicion\nthat the outbreaks of hepatitis E virus infection in Nagasaki and Tottori\nprefectures in 2003 (described in the ProMED-mail posts listed below) were\ninitiated by the consumption of improperly cooked wild boar meat. Hepatitis E\nvirus infection -- with its visible trademark, jaundice -- is sweeping\nacross the city's southern peninsula, say doctors. The\nWorld Health Organization (WHO) says hepatitis E is a waterborne disease\ntransmitted from person to person via the fecal-oral route. Contaminated\nwater or food supplies have been implicated in major outbreaks, it stated.\nPeople who have never contracted hepatitis are at risk of infection, WHO\nstated, and the disease finds fertile ground in areas of poor sanitation.\nHepatitis E virus infection is a mild to moderate disease in severity with\na mortality rate of 0.4-4.0 percent, WHO stated, 'except in pregnancy,\nwhere the mortality rate is progressively higher in each succeeding\ntrimester and may reach 20 percent'.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Hepatitis E virus (HEV), previously considered to be a calicivirus-like\nagent, is now ranked as a separate unassigned virus genus. Although similar\nin structure and genome organisation to caliciviruses, HEV exhibits weak\nphylogenetic links with rubella virus, alphaviruses, and plant furoviruses.\nIn humans, HEV is associated with outbreaks and sporadic cases of\nenterically transmitted acute hepatitis. It has an incubation period of 2-7\nweeks and appears to be spread mainly in water. Large water-borne epidemics\nhave occurred in India, and morbidity and mortality are greatest in\npregnant women. HEV is considered to be endemic in tropical and\nsub-tropical regions of Asia, Africa, and Central America. However,\nantibody prevalence suggests that the virus is distributed more widely in\nless pathogenic forms.\nAn outbreak of hepatitis E virus infection occurred in Bangui in July 2002\n(see reference below), and as in the present outbreak was thought to be\nassociated with fecal contamination of drinking water. It is unclear\nwhether the outbreak described above is due to poor sanitation or is\nindicative of the appearance of a strain of enhanced virulence. The officials said that their\nlimited ability to test for the virus had already been overwhelmed by the\nhepatitis outbreaks, suggesting that only a fraction of the actual cases\nhave been diagnosed. But in Sadr City, a Baghdad slum that for months has\nbeen convulsed by gun battles between a local militia and American troops,\nas many as 155 cases have turned up.\nThe 2nd outbreak is in Mahmudiya, a town 56 km (35 miles) south of Baghdad\nthat is known as much for its kidnappings and drive-by shootings as for its\npoverty, where 60 suspected cases have been seen. At least 9 pregnant women\nare believed to have been infected, and one has died. There have been 5\nreported deaths overall. 'We are saying that the real number is greatly\nmore than this, because the area is greatly underreported,' said Dr.\nAtta-alla Mekhlif al-Salmani, head of the viral hepatitis section at the\nHealth Ministry's Center for Disease Control.\nThe World Health Organization is rushing hepatitis E testing kits, water\npurification tablets, informational brochures and other materials to Iraq\nto help with the outbreaks, said Dr Naeema al-Gasseer, the health agency\nrepresentative for Iraq and a UN health official, who is now based in\nAmman, Jordan.\nBut viral hepatitis comes in numerous forms, and another ominous set of\nstatistics suggests that the quality of water supplies around the country\nhas deteriorated since the American-led invasion last year, Salmani said.\nIn 2003, there were 70 per cent more cases of hepatitis of all types\nreported across Iraq than in the year before, he said. During the first 6\nmonths of 2004, there were as many cases as in all of 2002.\nIn yet another indication of the deteriorating safety of both water and\nfood in Iraq, the number of reported cases of typhoid fever is up sharply\nthis year, said Dr Nima S Abid, the ministry's director general of public\nhealth and primary health. Hospitals across the country are also full of\nchildren with severe forms of diarrhea, Abid said.\nThe immediate reason for the outbreaks in Sadr City and Mahmudiya appear to\nbe easy to pin down, Abid said. The lack of infrastructure induces families\nto tap into water mains with improvised hoses, he said, citing his own\nvisits to the communities. They then use small electric pumps to bring\nwater into their homes. But in these same communities, sewage either seeps\nfrom damaged pipes into the ground or runs freely in the streets. This is the 1st\ntime it has been confirmed that more than 10 people had contracted\nhepatitis-E virus from the same source.\n\nDoctors suspect the 11 men may have either eaten meat that had not been\ngrilled thoroughly enough to kill the virus or used chopsticks that had\ntouched raw meat. 'Since hepatitis E virus is similar to hepatitis A virus,\nthe virus is generally killed if sufficiently heated. I urge people to be\ncareful when handling raw meat,' Koji Yano, a doctor at the National\nNagasaki Medical Center in Omura, said. [Hepatitis A virus and hepatitis E\nvirus are enteric viruses with similar routes of transmission and tissue\ntropism. They are not phylogenetically related, however: Hepatitis A virus\nis classified in the genus _Hepatovirus_ of the family _Picornaviridae_,\nwhereas Hepatitis E virus is more calicivurus-like but is now classified in\nthe unassigned genus _Hepevirus_. - Mod.CP]\n\n13 men aged between 64 and 82 held a barbecue party in Nagasaki Prefecture\nin March last year [2003] using meat from a wild boar they had caught,\naccording to Yano. 2 of the men, both aged 69, showed symptoms of acute\nhepatitis, such as lethargy and jaundice, in late April [2003], and\nunderwent a medical check-up at a hospital. The doctor who examined the 2\nsuspected that they may have contracted hepatitis from the wild boar and\nnotified the medical center. The center detected hepatitis-E virus in their\nblood samples. Noting that the genes of the virus in the 2 samples were\nalmost identical, doctors said the 2 men were infected from the same\nsource. The medical center managed to conduct tests on 10 of 11 other men\nwho had attended the party, and found 3 of them showed symptoms of acute\nhepatitis while 6 others had contracted the virus.\n\nInfection with hepatitis-E virus has occurred occasionally throughout the\ncountry on a smaller scale. In March 2003, 2 people living in Tottori\nPrefecture suffered from hepatitis-E after eating the raw liver of a wild\nboar, and one of them died later [see ProMED-mail post: 'Hepatitis E virus,\nwildlife to humans - Japan (03) 20030812.1996'].\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is globally distributed and is transmitted\nenterically as well as between humans and animals. Phylogenetic analysis\nhas identified 5 distinct HEV genotypes (types III and V have been\nconfirmed as present in Japan). In developing countries HEV is transmitted\nprincipally by the fecal-oral route, and water-borne epidemics are common.\nIn industrialized countries zoonotic transmission may be more usual.\nSporadic cases of hepatitis E have been reported in Japan in the past, and\nwidespread infection of HEV has been reported among wild rats in different\nparts of the country. Zoonotic spread of HEV is indicated by the fact that\nhuman and swine isolates of HEV are closely similar in terms of nucleotide\nsequence, and experimental cross-species transmission of swine HEV to a\nchimpanzee and of human HEV to swine have been demonstrated. The genetic\nrelatedness of Japanese human and swine HEV strains, and the possible modes\nof HEV transmission -- one of which is described above -- indicates that\nHEV should be considered in the diagnosis of acute or fulminant hepatitis\nof non-A, non-B, non-C etiology, even in Japanese patients who have not\ntraveled abroad. A recent survey suggests that generally 15.4 percent of\nJapanese patients with liver diseases had a history of HEV infection. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The genetic\nrelatedness of Japanese human and swine HEV strains, and the possible modes\nof HEV transmission -- one of which is described above -- indicates that\nHEV should be considered in the diagnosis of acute or fulminant hepatitis\nof non-A, non-B, non-C etiology, even in Japanese patients who have not\ntraveled abroad. Ali, 11, says his mother constantly cleans the cement in\nfront of his house trying to keep the water at bay. Ali's mother's\nattempts to keep things clean might be able to keep one family\nhealthy. But, the puddle of standing water, and others like it\nnearby, is probably the culprit in more than 100 recent cases of\nhepatitis E virus infection, a viral illness that feels like a bad\ncase of flu, commonly transmitted through human waste.\nThe outbreak was confirmed by Health Ministry officials (at the end\nof March 2004) in this poor neighborhood, said Buthaina Ghanem,\npublic health officer for the communicable diseases department of the\nUN World Health Organization's (WHO) Iraq office, working from Amman.\nOmar Mekki, a medical officer at WHO-Iraq, working from Amman, told\nIRIN that the Rustamiya sewage plant in central Baghdad, looted last\nApril 2004, still has not been fixed. Frequent power cuts stop water\npumps that keep sewage from flooding the streets. Even worse, the\nsewage can get sucked into drinking water supplies once the pumps\nstart again, Mekki said. 'The main sewage treatment plant is still\nnot working. It dumps one and a half tones of sewage into the Tigris\nriver everyday,' Mekki said. 'You can see it's pure sewage; the water\nis black.' With hot weather on the way, the ailing power grid will be\nfurther strained as millions of Iraqis resort to air conditioning to\nkeep cool.\nAs the high season for diarrheal disease approaches in Iraq, WHO and\nUS Center for Disease Control officials are trying to remind people\nto disinfect their water, Ghanem said. Officials recently passed out\nchlorination tablets and put up posters reminding families to boil\ntheir cooking water for at least 5 minutes, she said. 'It's under\ncontrol now,' Ghanem said. 'But hepatitis is everywhere. We're\nstruggling to keep it within a normal range.' So far in 2004,\ncholera, also often transmitted by water, has also been kept at bay,\nGhanem said.\nWHO officials are mandated to monitor water quality, but, the raw\nsewage problem is so enormous, it's impossible to measure, Mekki\nsaid. Water quality 'upstream' to the north of Baghdad is not that\nbad, but communities south of the capital bear the brunt of the\nsewage. Private contractor Bechtel Corp. was given the job of\nrepairing the Rustamiya sewage plant, according to Jan Kellett,\nUnited Nations Development Program (UNDP) Iraq press officer in\nAmman. Poor security in the neighborhood apparently has kept Bechtel\nfrom finishing the project, Kellett said. Bechtel officials were not\nimmediately available for comment. The jaundice attack, diagnosed as hepatitis E virus\ninfection by the authorities, has spread without warning around the central\nCine Nacionale-Azad Maidan area of Panjim. It is believed to have been\ncaused by the flow of filthy water from the kitchen of a local hotel into\nthe main pipeline.\nPanjim 'has been witnessing an unprecedented rush of people to private\nclinics for getting themselves checked for jaundice, most of whom are\nsubsequently tested positive', reported The Navhind Times daily.\nGoa Health Minister Suresh Amonkar told newspapers that a couple of the\nreported deaths were not due to jaundice but due to liver cirrhosis. At the\nsame time, he appealed to city residents and restaurants to consume boiled\nwater. The government has also dropped hints of 'stern action' against\nunhygienic restaurants and roadside kiosks.\nBold newspaper advertisements warn citizens to 'protect yourself from viral\nhepatitis (jaundice),' which spreads through contaminated water and food.\n'The virus is not killed by chlorination of water. It is destroyed by\nboiling the water,' say the advertisements. Authorities have called on\ncitizens to avoid fruits or juices sold 'on the roadside' and ice-candies\nfrom 'unapproved sources'. The warnings say only freshly cooked food should\nbe eaten when hot. They remind medical practitioners that they should\nnotify [the authorities of] any cases of the disease.\nIncidentally, Goa's former capital of Old Goa, once a beautiful capital of\nthe Portuguese maritime empire in Asia, had fallen to a terrible epidemic,\nafter which the viceroy's residence was transferred to current-day capital\nPanaji in 1759. A construction boom has also made parts of Goa prone to\nmalaria, which has afflicted nearly 10 000 people in the state of 1.35 million.\n--\nHerman Carneiro\nEpidemiologist\nInfectious Disease Control\nBoston, MA, USA\n<herman.carneiro@state.ma.us>\n[Hepatitis E virus is a single-stranded RNA virus belonging to a unique\ngenus. It displays a strong tropism for hepatocytes and is transmitted via\nthe fecal-oral route. It is responsible for an acute self-limited infection\ncharacterized as acute hepatic inflammation. Swine, rats, and some other\nanimals may act as alternate hosts. The earliest documented cases of\nhepatitis E virus infection occurred in India (Dehli) in 1955 after heavy\nflooding. Subsequently sporadic outbreaks have been recorded throughout\nAsia, Africa, and Central America, usually in association with contaminated\ndrinking water. ProMED-mail and Dr. Carneiro would welcome further\ninformation about this outbreak of hepatitis E virus infection in Goa and\nprogress in its control. Professor Hiroaki Okamoto of Jichi Medical School in Tochigi\nPrefecture will report these findings in a British medical journal.\nHowever, he said the chance of infection with HEV from pork livers is slim.\n'You can't get infected with HEV from eating pork flesh. And you don't have\nto worry about pork livers if you sufficiently heat them up before eating.'\nIn his research, Professor Okamoto purchased 363 packs of pork livers at\nsupermarkets in Hokkaido and detected HEV genome sequences in 7, or 1.9 per\ncent of them. The sequence found in 3 of the 7 samples is identical to that\nof the HEV virus found in a Japanese HEV patient.\nNine out of 10 HEV patients who developed illness in Hokkaido between 2001\nand 2002 had eaten pork livers, according to Okamoto. Pork liver sashimi is\nconsidered a delicacy in Japan, although many people, especially women,\nfind it revolting.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It is likely that farmed pigs as well as wild-living pigs may harbour\nhepatitis E virus. The low\nfrequency of detection of hepatitis E virus sequences in meat purchased in\nsupermarkets, however, could be explained also by contamination of the pig\nmeat from a human source during its preparation for sale. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n --------------------------------------------------------------------------\nHepatitis E virus (HEV) genome sequences has been detected in pork livers\nsold at supermarkets, a team led by a medical university professor has\nfound. The affected areas\nare Chasipara, Lalgarh, Moyrapara, Azadgarh, Burmanpara, Sethbagan,\nChasirmat, Goalabagan, Basakbagan, and Swamiji colony of the Municipal\nareas of South Dum Dum. The outbreak appears to be due to contamination of\nthe water supply in the affected areas. The main manifestation was\njaundice. Although at least 15 relapse cases were reported in Moyrapara,\nAzadgarh, and Goalabagan areas, there was no report of any death from the\ndisease. It has been observed that about 30 percent of the cases have\nalready been cured.\nVirologists attached to the School of Tropical Medicine, Kolkata have\nexamined 20 blood samples from the affected persons, out of which 15\nsamples were positive for hepatitis E virus IgM antibody. At present,\ndrinking water is being supplied by 12 large tankers, halogen tablets are\nbeing distributed, and health workers have already visited at least 280\nhouses. Municipality engineers are now planning for the replacement of 1000\nmeters of asbestos water supply pipeline -- where contamination was\nsuspected -- with iron pipes.\n--\nDr. Satadal Das, M.D., D.C.P.\nConsultant Microbiologist & Infection Control Officer,\nPeerless Hospital & B. K. Roy Research Centre,\nKolkata-700 094, India.\n<sdas201@hotmail.com>\n[Like many enteric viruses, hepatitis E virus possesses a single-stranded\npositive-sense RNA genome within an icosahedral particle. However, it is\nnot closely related, phylogenetically, to other enteric viruses but is\nclassified as a unique virus genus. Hepatitis E virus displays a strong\ntropism for hepatocytes, and it is transmitted via the fecal-oral route. It\nis responsible for an acute self-limited infection characterized as acute\nhepatic inflammation. It has been claimed, however, that in endemic areas\nin India, hepatitis E virus may be a common cause of acute liver failure.\nThe earliest documented cases of hepatitis E virus infection occurred in\nIndia (Dehli) in 1955 after heavy flooding. Subsequently sporadic outbreaks\nhave been recorded throughout Asia, Africa, and Central America, usually in\nassociation with contaminated drinking water. Pigs, rats, deer, and some\nother animals may act as alternate hosts. No vaccine is available at\npresent. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 23 Apr 2004\n \nDr. Satadal Das, M.D., D.C.P.\nConsultant Microbiologist & Infection Control Officer,\nPeerless Hospital & B.
