Japan (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204281", "date": "2003-08-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "HEPATITIS E VIRUS, WILDLIFE TO HUMANS - JAPAN (02)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 3 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Yomiuri Shimbun, Sat 2 Aug 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/newse/20030802wo32.htm>\n\nJapan: Fatal Hepatitis E Virus Infection From Consumption of Raw Boar Meat\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------\nA 70-year-old man from Tottori Prefecture died in April 2003 of hepatitis E\nvirus infection after eating raw wild boar [meat] that carried the\nHepatitis E virus, The Yomiuri Shimbun newspaper learned on Fri 1 Aug 2003.\nIt also was learned that a 53-year-old man in the same prefecture who ate\nthe meat also contracted the disease, as well as 4 people in Hyogo\nPrefecture who ate raw deer meat earlier this year.\nThe Health, Labor and Welfare Ministry will issue a warning to prefectural\ngovernments on the dangers of eating the raw flesh of wild animals, sources\nclose to the ministry said on Friday. The Ministry also is considering\nconducting a nationwide survey on what kinds of animals and how many of\nthem have the virus.\nIn the Hyogo Prefecture case, 3 people in a family and a friend received\nsome venison from an acquaintance in late February 2003 and ate it raw, the\nsources said. All 4, aged between 40 to 69, displayed symptoms of the\ndisease, including high fever, vomiting, and impaired hepatic function in\nApril. They were examined at Kasai Municipal Hospital in Kasai, Hyogo\nPrefecture, and diagnosed as having the virus. The 4 victims recovered from\nthe ill effects of eating the meat without developing chronic hepatitis E\nvirus infection. [Hepatitis E virus infection, like that of hepatitis A\nvirus, causes an acute self-limited disease that does not progress to a\nchronic phase. - Mod.CP]\nA team of researchers led by Shunji Mishiro, director of the research\ndepartment of Toshiba Hospital in Tokyo, examined a sample of the venison\nfrom the family's freezer and detected hepatitis E virus with a gene\nidentical to the virus found in the victims. In the Tottori case, the 2\nvictims were confirmed as having contracted the disease after eating the\nuncooked internal organs of a wild boar.\nHepatitis E can be contracted through tainted water and food. Until\nrecently, it had been considered a disease of developing countries with\npoor sanitary conditions, but Mishiro found that it has claimed the lives\nof Japanese people since the 1990s. According to experts, consumers do not\nneed to worry even if meat contains the virus, provided it is fully cooked.\n'The virus is usually killed off by heat, but the risk level of eating the\nmeat of wild animals is totally unknown. We'll investigate the situation as\nsoon as possible,' a ministry official said. Hepatitis E virus is the only\nhepatitis virus that can be spread through zoonosis.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report and the preceding report from Japan on hepatitis E virus\ninfection reveal a previously unrecognized risk associated with consumption\nof raw meat from wild animals. Hepatitis E virus infection is usually\nassociated with water-borne outbreaks of illness or sporadic cases of\nenterically transmitted acute hepatitis. As previously commented, hepatitis\nE virus is considered to be endemic in tropical regions of Asia, Africa,\nand Central America, and non-pathogenic variants are presumed to be present\nmore widely. On the basis of immunological studies, related or identical\nhepatitis E viruses infect primates, swine, and other animals. In Japan --\nat least -- these other animals are now known to include wild boar and Sika\ndeer. The virus recovered from refrigerated raw venison from Sika deer and\nthe human patients proved to be virtually identical by limited nucleic acid\nsequence comparison, confirming the previous inference from immunological\nstudies that some human and animal strains of hepatitis E virus are closely\nrelated. The outcome of hepatitis E virus infection is not normally\nserious, except in the case of pregnant women in the third trimester of\npregnancy, when a case-fatality rate of 15-20 percent has been observed.\nFulminant hepatitis occurs more often in economically deprived communities.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "The virus recovered from refrigerated raw venison from Sika deer and\nthe human patients proved to be virtually identical by limited nucleic acid\nsequence comparison, confirming the previous inference from immunological\nstudies that some human and animal strains of hepatitis E virus are closely\nrelated. 'When the medical doctor coordinating\nBegoua Health Centre informed us on 22 Jul 2002, we sent an assessment\nmission there that concluded that there was a serious problem,' Dr Carlos\nRecio, the medical coordinator of Medicos Sin Fronteras-Spain (MSF), told\nIRIN on Wed 9 Oct 2002. He added that the first blood tests carried out by\nInstitut Pasteur from Tuesday to Wednesday showed that 48 of 98 cases tested\npositive for the [virus].\nAn emergency committee comprising officials from the Ministry of Health,\nMSF, the World Health Organisation (WHO), the Institut Pasteur, and the\nNational Laboratory has been set up to tackle the problem. The WHO says the\nhepatitis E virus causes acute sporadic and epidemic viral hepatitis.\nTypical symptoms of the disease include jaundice, anorexia, inflammation of\nthe liver, abdominal pain and tenderness, nausea and vomiting, and fever, it\nsays. The disease is spread via the oral-faecal route, and has been\nimplicated in several food and waterborne outbreaks, WHO says. 'Consumption\nof faecally contaminated drinking water has given rise to epidemic cases,\nand the ingestion of raw or uncooked shellfish has been the source of\nsporadic cases in endemic areas,' the UN agency reports.\nMSF, the CAR Red Cross, and a local NGO, Jeunesse centrafricaine conquerante\npour le developpement, have intensified the public information campaign in\nthe different neighbourhoods of Begoua. WHO says control measures against\nthe disease should include the provision of safe drinking water and proper\ndisposal of sanitary waste and other measures. In line with this, MSF has\nproposed that wells be dug at least 30 metres away from latrines, & that the\ngovernment strictly enforce laws on domestic animals and provide the public\nwith clean water. 'We hope that with the dry season the epidemic will\ndisappear,' Recio said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Hepatitis E virus (HEV), previously considered to be a calicivirus-like\nagent, is now ranked as a separate unassigned genus. Although similar in\nstructure and genome organisation to caliciviruses, HEV exhibits weak\nphylogenetic links with rubella virus, alphaviruses, and plant furoviruses.\nIn humans, HEV is associated with outbreaks and sporadic cases of\nenterically transmitted acute hepatitis. It has an incubation period of 2-7\nweeks and appears to be spread mainly in water. Large water-borne epidemics\nhave occurred in India and morbidity and mortality are greatest in pregnant\nwomen. HEV is considered to be endemic in tropical and sub-tropical regions\nof Asia, Africa, and Central America. However, antibody prevalence suggests\nthat the virus is distributed more widely in less pathogenic forms.\nA virus closely related to HEV has been isolated from swine. It is unclear\nwhether the outbreak described above is due to poor sanitation or is\nindicative of the appearance of a strain of enhanced virulence. - Mod.CP]\n(see also:\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824\nHepatitis E virus, new genotypes - Japan (04) 20020724.4856\n2001\n----\nHepatitis E, epidemiology - Spain 20011005.2411\nHepatitis E virus, rat-borne? - USA 20011123.2871\n2000\n----\nHepatitis E virus, full-length clone 20000223.0247\n1999\n----\nHepatitis E: emerging zoonosis? 19990121.0099\n1996\n----\nHepatitis E - Nepal 19961231.2164]\n........................mpp/cp/pg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Shuchin Tei and\ncolleagues have identified potential zoonotic transmission of HEV from\nJapanese Sika deer (_Cervus nippon nippon_).\n\nOver several weeks members of 2 [human] families developed hepatitis\nsymptoms, but were negative for hepatitis A, B, and C viruses. Physicians\ndiscovered the patients had several times eaten raw meat from deer caught in\nthe wild in the 7 weeks preceding the first hospital admission. Fortunately,\nleftover meat had been frozen and dated at the time of eating. HEV RNA\nsequences in the meat of one deer and most of the patients' samples were 100\npercent identical. Shuchin Tei and colleagues conclude that this finding is\ndirect evidence of zoonotic HEV transmission.\n\nHowever, they believe consumption of substantial amounts of raw deer meat is\nnecessary for transmission, since eating only a little did not lead to\ninfection in other family members.\n\n--\nAkira Goto\n<dolphin@mail.ne.jp>\n\n[The Research Letter from Shuchin Tei, Naoto Kitajima, Kazuaki Takahashi, and\nShunji Mishiro is entitled 'Zoonotic transmission of hepatitis E virus from\ndeer to human beings.'\n\nHepatitis E virus is is a single-stranded positive-sense RNA virus which has\ncharacteristics (morphology and genome organization) in common with members\nof the family _Caliciviridae_, but it is sufficiently distinct\nphylogenetically to remain classified as a distinct unassigned genus.\nHepatitis E virus has been associated with water-borne outbreaks of illness\nand sporadic cases of enterically transmitted acute hepatitis. Hepatitis E\nvirus is considered to be endemic in tropical regions of Asia, Africa, and\nCentral America, and non-pathogenic variants may be present globally. On the\nbasis of immunological studies, related or identical hepatitis E viruses\ninfect primates, swine, and other animals, to which now can be added Sika\ndeer. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Japan is a distinctly non-tropical country, so maybe wildlife from temperate\nregion countries should be examined also. Sika deer are indigenous to Asia,\nbut have been introduced into zoos & parks in many countries, notably\nMadagascar, South Africa, New Zealand & various Pacific island countries, USA\n(e.g. KY, MD, TX), UK & 7 other European countries, into which they have\nescaped and are breeding in the wild, and also hybridizing with indigenous\ndeer in England & Texas. It would be interesting to discover whether those\nare also harboring hepatitis E virus, and whether their meat is eaten raw in\nthose countries. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "Shunji Mishiro is entitled 'Zoonotic transmission of hepatitis E virus from\ndeer to human beings.'\n\nHepatitis E virus is is a single-stranded positive-sense RNA virus which has\ncharacteristics (morphology and genome organization) in common with members\nof the family _Caliciviridae_, but it is sufficiently distinct\nphylogenetically to remain classified as a distinct unassigned genus. The first post\non this subject pointed the finger at rats, pigs, and goats. The fact\nthat '...a number of HEV-like sequences have also been isolated from\nswine worldwide, suggesting the potential of an animal reservoir', as\nthe moderator added, is not enough to validate making such claims.\nZoonotic transmission of this virus seems to have grown into mythic\nproportions. If anyone has studies that prove otherwise I would very\nmuch like to hear of them.\n--\nRadford G. Shapiro <dshapiro@bu.edu>\n\nA Comment on the Transmission of Hepatitis Viruses\n--------------------------------------------------\nIn the Yomiuri Shimbun article that is the source of the ProMED-mail\nposting on new genotypes of hepatitis E virus [archived as 'Hepatitis\nE virus, new genotypes - Japan 20020721.4824'], it is stated that 'Of\nthe main viral forms of [hepatitis], which inflames the liver, only\nhepatitis E virus infection can be spread by animals.'\nThis is not correct. Hepatitis A infections have been transmitted to\nhumans from non-human primates (1). More than 200 cases of hepatitis\nA virus infection have been transmitted from non-human primates to\nhumans (2), primarily from chimpanzees (_Pan troglodytes_). Other\nnon-human primates, including woolly monkeys, siamangs, Celebes\ncrested apes, and gorillas have transmitted hepatitis A virus to\nhumans.\nNeedless to say, given that chimpanzees have been experimentally\ninfected with hepatitis B and C viruses, there is at least the\ntheoretical possibility that humans could acquire these infections\nfrom infected chimpanzees, but I am unaware of any documented cases\nof transmission to humans.\nReferences:\n-----------\n1. Of the main\nviral forms of [hepatitis], which inflames the liver, only hepatitis E\nvirus infection can be spread by animals. The Health, Labor and Welfare\nMinistry began researching the number of cases of hepatitis E virus\ninfection and studying the route of infection, after Europe and the United\nStates reported increased [incidence] of the disease in recent years. The 3\npatients who died were diagnosed with hepatitis E virus infection during\nautopsies. Among them was a Hokkaido woman who was diagnosed with acute\nhepatitis 6 days after being admitted to a hospital last year and later\nunderwent a partial liver transplant from a living donor. However, she died\n3 months after the operation.\nA research team led by Shunji Mishiro, director of Toshiba Hospital's\nresearch department, detected hepatitis E virus (HEV) when testing her\nblood after her death. Another research group also found HEV in the serums\nof 2 elderly men of the Tohoku Region who died of acute hepatitis in the 1990s.\nThe cases, the first fatalities confirmed to be caused by hepatitis E virus\nin the nation, were reported to a meeting of experts last month. Mishiro\nand his team also detected HEV in the blood of 7 patients in Tokyo, Saitama\nPrefecture and Hokkaido who had been diagnosed with acute hepatitis between\n1996 and 2002. As none of the 7 had been to places abroad where the disease\nis prevalent, experts said it is likely the virus has taken root in the\ncountry. Cases of people returning from abroad with the illness also have\nbeen confirmed.\nExaminations found 3 [genotypes] of HEV among the 7 people who contracted\nthe virus in Japan, all of which were different from the types of the virus\nfound overseas. Mishiro determined that HEV came to the country through 3\nroutes. HEV, as with hepatitis A virus (HAV), is contained in patients'\nstools, and can be caught through consuming food or water contaminated by\nfeces from an infected person.\nAccording to studies in areas where the virus is rampant, hepatitis virus\ninfection E can become more serious than hepatitis A. The virus is fatal in\n1-2 percent of cases; a death rate 10 times that of hepatitis A. About 20\npercent of pregnant women who contract acute hepatitis E die.\nIn Japan, HEV has not been considered a serious risk because it has been\nassociated with countries with underdeveloped water supplies. In light of\nthis and the fact that HEV testing is not widely available, it is possible\nthat other people infected with the virus have gone undiagnosed. HEV can\n[survive] and grow in the body of animals without causing serious problems\nto its host. Therefore, pigs, goats, and rats are thought to carry the\nvirus in some foreign countries. As the virus can spread if left unchecked,\nthe ministry is trying to determine as soon as possible the number of\nhepatitis E cases among patients infected with unspecified forms of acute\nhepatitis.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As stated above, Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection has been associated\nwith developing regions and attributed to oral-fecal transmission due to\ninadequate sanitation. Several recent findings, however, have led to a new\nunderstanding of this virus. A number of novel isolates have been\nidentified in patients with acute hepatitis from regions other than Japan\nnot considered endemic for HEV (Austria, the Netherlands, New Zealand,\nSpain, and the United States). These individuals reported no recent travel\nto HEV-endemic areas. In addition, a number of HEV-like sequences have also\nbeen isolated from swine worldwide, suggesting the potential of an animal\nreservoir.\nThe August issue of the Journal of General Virology (83(Pt 8):1931-1940,\n2002) contains a paper by Takahashi et al. describing the identification\nof 2 distinct genotypes of hepatitis E virus in a Japanese patient with\nacute hepatitis who had not travelled abroad. The paper should be consulted\nfor an up-to-date assessment of the situation. The authors conclude among\nother things that one of the 2 strains had higher sequence identity to\nhuman and swine HEV isolates from the United States (US1, US2 and swUS1)\nthan to those reported thus far from Japan (JRA1 and swJ570). The 2\nco-infecting strains identified from the single patient shared only 80.1\npercent nucleotide identity. These results indicate that multiple genotypes\nof HEV co-circulate in Japan, and that genotype IV comprises a remarkably\nheterogeneous group of HEVs. It seems clear that at least 4 distinct\ngenotypes of hepatitis E virus are prevalent in Japan and that this should\nbe taken into account in the treatment of acute hepatitis. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "As the virus can spread if left unchecked,\nthe ministry is trying to determine as soon as possible the number of\nhepatitis E cases among patients infected with unspecified forms of acute\nhepatitis.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The August issue of the Journal of General Virology (83(Pt 8):1931-1940,\n2002) contains a paper by Takahashi et al. describing the identification\nof 2 distinct genotypes of hepatitis E virus in a Japanese patient with\nacute hepatitis who had not travelled abroad. Meng, M.D., Ph.D. <xjmeng@vt.edu>\n\nRemarks on Dr. Radford Davis's comments regarding Zoonotic\nTransmission of Hepatitis E Virus\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------\n[In the proMED-mail post archived as 'Hepatitis E virus, new\ngenotypes - Japan (03) 20020724.4850'] Dr. Davis [referring to\nnon-human primates] commented that he was 'unaware of any evidence\nthat proves any other animal species is capable of harboring\nhepatitis E virus (HEV) and transmitting it to humans'. If anyone\ncares to do a literature search or knows anything about HEV, he/she\nwould find that there is ample evidence documenting otherwise.\nPigs and chickens have been confirmed to harbor HEV, and the HEV\ngenomic sequences in these animal species have been determined. Swine\nHEV and avian HEV are genetically and antigenically related to human\nHEV. It has been shown that swine HEV infects chimpanzees and rhesus\nmonkeys and conversely human HEV infects pigs. In addition, pig\nveterinarians and pig handlers in several countries (including the\nU.S.) had significantly higher anti-HEV prevalence compared to\nmatched control blood donor populations. Human HEV strains resembling\nswine HEV have been identified from patients in a number of\nindustrialized countries, including 2 US patients. The viruses\nrecovered from the 2 US patients are extremely similar to the\nprototype swine HEV, and the US human HEV infects pigs.\nUS Army scientists have reported the detection and genetic\nidentification of a HEV strain from rodents, and the 'murine HEV' is\nclosely related to human HEV. In addition to pigs, human HEV has been\nsuccessfully transmitted to rats and lambs. Furthermore, there are a\nnumber of other animal species (cats, dogs, cattle, etc.) that have\nbeen found to be seropositive.\nWhat evidence do we need for a zoonosis claim? Our lab is responsible\nfor the discovery of the swine and avian hepatitis E viruses (see\nreferences below). In my opinion, the claim that hepatitis E is a\nzoonosis and that animal reservoirs exist, is very appropriate and\nthis concept has been accepted by the hepatitis E research community.\nThe 4th International Conference on Emerging Zoonosis will have a\ntopic on Hepatitis E.\nReferences:\n1. Kasorndorkbua, C. B.J. Thacker, P.G. Halbur, D.K. Guenette, R.\nBeitenwerf, R. L. Royer, and X.J. Meng. Experimental Infection of\nSwine Hepatitis E Virus in Pregnant Gilts. American Journal of\nVeterinary Research.\n2. Engle RE, Yu C, Emerson SU, Meng XJ, and Purcell RH (2002).\nHepatitis E virus (HEV) capsid antigen derived from virus of human or\nswine origin is equally efficient for detecting anti-HEV by enzyme\nimmunoassay. Journal of Clinical Microbiology.\n3. Sun, Z.F., F.F. Huang, H.L. Shivaprasad, P.R. Woolcock, P.G.\nHalbur, S.K. Schommer, T.E. Toth, and X.J. Meng (2002). Use of\nheteroduplex mobility assays (HMA) for pre-sequence screening of\navian and swine hepatitis E viruses. Journal of Virological Methods.\n4. Huang, F.F., G. Haqshenas, D.K. Guenette, F.W. Pierson, H.L.\nShrivaprasad, T.E. Toth, and X.J. Meng (2002). Experimental infection\nof embryonated chicken eggs, 1-day-old chickens,\nspecific-pathogen-free layer chickens and broiler breeder chickens\nwith avian HEV: a first assessment. Journal of Clinical Microbiology.\n5. Huang FF, G.Haqshenas, D.K. Guenette, P.R. Woolcock, H.L.\nShrivaprasad, C.T. Larsen, F.W. Pierson, T.E. Toth, X.J. Meng (2002).\nHeterogeneity and seroprevalence of the newly-identified avian\nhepatitis E virus from chickens in the United States. Journal of\nClinical Microbiology. In Press\n6. Huang, F.F., G.Haqshenas, D.K. Guenette, P.G. Halbur, S.Schommer,\nF.W. Pierson, T.E. Toth and X.J. Meng (2002). Detection by RT-PCR and\ngenetic characterization of field isolates of swine hepatitis E virus\nfrom pigs in different geographic regions of the U.S. Journal of\nClinical Microbiology. 40:1326-1332.\n7. Meng, X.J. (2002). Swine hepatitis E virus: cross-species\ninfections into humans. In: C. Wilson and D. Salamon (eds) Current\nTopics in Microbiology and Immunology: Xenotransplantation.\nSpringer-Verlag, NY. In Press.\n8. Haqshenas G., F.F. Huang, M. Fenaux, D.K. Guenette, F.W. Pierson,\nH.L. Shivaprasda, T.E. Toth and X.J. Meng (2002). The putative capsid\nprotein of the newly identified avian hepatitis E virus shares\nantigenic epitopes with that of swine and human hepatitis E viruses\nand the chicken big liver and spleen disease virus. Journal of\nGeneral Virology. 83:2201-2209.\n9. Kasorndorkbua, C., P.G. Halbur, D.K. Guenette, T.E. Toth, X.J.\nMeng (2002). Use of a swine bioassay and a RT-PCR assay to assess the\nrisk of transmission of swine hepatitis E virus in pigs. Journal of\nVirological Methods. 101:71-78.\n10. Wu, J.C., CM Chen, TY Chiang, WH Tsai, WJ Jeng, IJ Sheen, JY\nChen, CC Lin, X.J. Meng (2002). Potential Subclinical spread of HEV\namong swine, swine handlers and different countries: a longitudinal\nstudy. Journal of Medical Virology. 66:488-492.\n11. Meng X.J., B. Wiseman, D. Guenette, R. HEPATITIS E VIRUS, NEW GENOTYPES - JAPAN (04)\n******************************************** Zoonotic and xenozoonotic risks of the\nhepatitis E virus. It has been shown that swine HEV infects chimpanzees and rhesus\nmonkeys and conversely human HEV infects pigs. Pigs and chickens have been confirmed to harbor HEV, and the HEV\ngenomic sequences in these animal species have been determined. In addition to pigs, human HEV has been\nsuccessfully transmitted to rats and lambs. M. Favorov, O. Nazarova and\nH. Margolis. U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Atlanta,\nGeorgia; Institute Prevention Medicine, Ashgabad, Turkmenistan.\nAccording to an abstract submitted by the authors to the 2nd International\nConference on Emerging Zoonoses, held 5-9 Nov 1998, in Strasbourg, France,\n'Limited studies indicate that a substantial proportion of acute viral\nhepatitis that occurs in Asia, the Indian subcontinent, Africa and Mexico\nis caused by hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection. Non-human primates have\nbeen shown to be susceptible to experimental HEV infection and HEV RNA\n[ribonucleic acid] antibody to HEV (anti-HEV) were found among domestic\nswine in Nepal.\nRecently, a novel virus closely related to the HEV was identified that has\na 80% identity with human HEV. However, swine are not raised in most\nregions of Asia known to have high endemic rates of HEV infection.\nTo investigate whether HEV infection occurs in other domestic animals,\nanti-HEV activity was determine in 354 serum specimens obtained from 1-2\nyear old cows living in three countries where HEV infection has been shown\nto be highly endemic (Somalia, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan) and one country\nwhere HEV infection has not been reported (Ukraine). Anti-HEV activity was\nfound in 29%-62% of animals from high endemic countries. The prevalence of\nantibody was highest in Somalia, a country where an outbreak of hepatitis E\noccurred prior to the collection of the serum samples. Compared to high\nendemic countries, the prevalence of anti-HEV was 11.9% in the Ukraine\n(p<0.001), a country where hepatitis E outbreaks have not occurred. In the\nTurkmenistan Republic, the anti-HEV activity among 52 domestic animals\n(cows, sheep, and goats) was 42%-67%, with no difference between species.\nAnti-HEV activity was found in 20% of animals less than 6 month of age, the\nprevalence in adults was 57%-60%, and antibody activity in animals varied\nbetween farms (27% to 78%, P<0.04).\nThe presence of past HEV infection among domestic animals in areas with a\nhigh endemicity of human infection suggests the zoonotic nature of this\ndisease.'\n--\nEric Nojie\ne-mail: nojie@who.ch\n[Although the evidence here is suggestive of a zoonotic nature, it would be\ninteresting to know if any of the studies have been repeated. - Mod.TG]\n................................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
